questions.text: A mother brought her 6-year-old son to the OPD with complaints of frequent bedwetting even after behavioral and lifestyle modification and correction. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Desmopressin:

  • It is the DOC in nocturnal enuresis.
  • It is a synthetic ADH which decreases urine volume

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Oxybutynin: It is an anticholinergic that relaxes the detrusor muscle of the bladder

Option C - Imipramine: It is a tricyclic antidepressant and has anticholinergic properties

Option D - Alarm method: This is a lifestyle modification which is a first-line treatment done in nocturnal enuresis.

questions.text: Which among the following rickets is also known as Vitamin D-resistant rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - VDDR type 2:

  • This is also known as Vitamin D-resistant rickets
  • End organ resistance to 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit D3 At the level of receptors

Clinical Features

  • Early onset Rickets
  • High prevalence of alopecia and ectodermal defects:(oligodontia, Milia, Epidermal cysts)

Investigations

  • Hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia
  • Secondary hyper PTH
  • Elevated 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit D3 Level

Treatment

  • A large dose of Ca2+ for a prolonged period
  • Responses to treatment are not satisfactory

Incorrect Options:

Option A - VDDR type 1

Option C - Familial Hypophosphatemic Rickets

Option D - Nutritional rickets

  • These are not known by Vitamin D-resistant rickets

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He complained of suprapubic pain, difficulty in the ability to pass urine and hematuria. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any urinary tract abnormalities. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. A pelvic x-ray of the patient was done, which revealed a pelvic fracture. The cystography of the patient is done, which is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Extraperitoneal bladder rupture:

  • This is a case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture in which the patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with complaints of suprapubic pain, difficulty in the ability to pass urine and hematuria.
  • The x-ray of the pelvis reveals a pelvic fracture.
  • The cystography of the patient is given in the case, which reveals a flame sign and teardrop-shaped bladder, which is suggestive of extraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • In extraperitoneal bladder rupture, the bladder is clearly visible in the pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intraperitoneal bladder rupture:

  • In intraperitoneal bladder rupture, there is history of an external blow to the bladder, a distended bladder and peritonitis.
  • cystrography shows intraperitoneal contrast material around bowel loops, mesentric folds and paracolic gutters. 

Option C - Bladder contusion:

  • An incomplete or partial thickness tear in the bladder results in bladder contusion.
  • It usually results due to blunt trauma to the bladder.
  • Cystography in bladder contusion reveals hematoma in the bladder.

Option D - Posterior urethral injury:

  • In posterior urethral injuries, there are significant bladder fractures due to trauma.
  • The membranous bulb junction is most commonly injured in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is NOT considered part of Basic emergency Obs care services?

choices.text: Assisted vaginal delivery in Community Health Centers (CHCs)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Blood transfusion:

  • Basic emergency obstetric care includes essential interventions that can be provided at the first referral level of healthcare facilities, typically at health centers.
  • These interventions are crucial for managing obstetric emergencies and reducing maternal mortality.
  • Blood transfusion is a part of comprehensive emergency obstetric care.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C: These are incorrect as they are included under Basic emergency Obs care

questions.text: A 14-week-old infant is brought to the primary healthcare center for routine vaccination. Upon reviewing the vaccination schedule, the healthcare provider instructs the nurse to administer vaccines as indicated. The nurse realizes that the refrigerator storing the vaccines malfunctioned overnight, causing potential damage to some of the vaccines due to freezing temperatures. Which of the following vaccines among the options is least likely to be affected by freezing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Measles:

  • The measles vaccine is the least likely to be affected by freezing temperatures compared to the other vaccines listed.
  • While it's important to prevent freezing, the measles vaccine tends to maintain its potency even if exposed to brief periods of cold.
  • It's considered relatively stable and less sensitive to freezing compared to other vaccines.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hepatitis B:

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is indeed sensitive to freezing temperatures. Freezing can damage the vaccine and reduce its effectiveness.

Option B - DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus):

  • DPT vaccine is also sensitive to freezing temperatures. Exposure to freezing can lead to loss of potency, rendering the vaccine less effective.

Option C - Pentavalent:

  • Pentavalent vaccine typically includes antigens against diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib).
  • Pentavalent vaccine is a heat-sensitive vaccine.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a gradual decrease in vision and glare. A slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral, linear, branching, and refractile lines in the cornea, as shown in the image below. The condition is associated with recurrent corneal erosions and may lead to corneal scarring. This presentation is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lattice dystrophy:

  • Lattice dystrophy is characterized by the presence of linear, branching, and refractile lattice lines in the cornea as shown in the image given. These lines are visible upon slit-lamp examination. Patients with lattice dystrophy often experience a gradual decrease in vision .

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granular dystrophy: Granular dystrophy is the deposition of Hyaline in the stroma, O/E sugar granules like round opacity with a clear cornea between the opacities. It has an autosomal dominant pattern of  inheritance.

Option C - Macular dystrophy: Macular dystrophy primarily affects the central cornea and is characterized by the presence of round, grayish-white opacities, and the cornea appears hazy between the opacities. 

Option D - Schnyder crystalline dystrophy: Schnyder crystalline dystrophy is characterized by the deposition of cholesterol crystals within the cornea, leading to a cloudy appearance. It does not typically present with linear lattice lines.

questions.text: What term best describes the phenomenon exhibited by a 35- year-old male who while speaking, switches topics abruptly and displays continuous speech flow with no pauses or breaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Flight of ideas

  • Flight of ideas refers to rapid, continuous speech with abrupt shifts from one topic to another, often with superficial or loose connections between ideas.

  • It is commonly seen in mania, where the person appears to be talking non-stop and jumping between topics.

  • The speech is pressured, and the transitions may follow understandable associations, even if tenuous.

Definitions:

Term Definition
Derailment Also known as loosening of associations, where ideas slip off track onto unrelated tangents. Unlike flight of ideas, connections are not logical or understandable.
Thought blocking A sudden interruption in speech or thought, where the patient abruptly stops speaking, often reporting a “blank mind.” Seen in schizophrenia.
Neologism The creation of new, meaningless words that are not part of any recognized language. Common in schizophrenia.

 

Derailment (Option A):
Incorrect – There is a lack of connection between ideas, whereas in flight of ideas, the flow remains connected superficially.

Thought blocking (Option B):
Incorrect – Describes a sudden halt in speech, not rapid continuous speech.

Neologism (Option D):
Incorrect – Refers to newly made-up words, not rapid topic shifting.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is scheduled for a nerve block procedure, and the anesthesia team is considering the use of adrenaline (epinephrine) to enhance the effects of the local anesthetic. In this context, in which of the following nerve blocks should the administration of adrenaline be avoided to prevent potential complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Penile nerve block:

  • The inclusion of adrenaline extends the duration of action of a local anesthetic by inducing vasoconstriction and reducing the absorption of the local anesthetic into the systemic circulation.
  • Adrenaline should be avoided in areas with end arterial supply, such as the penis, pinna, tip of the nose, and the distal parts of fingers and toes, as its use may lead to ischemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brachial plexus block:

  • Adrenaline is commonly added to the local anesthetic in brachial plexus blocks. The vasoconstrictive effects of adrenaline help prolong the duration of anesthesia and reduce systemic absorption.

Option C - Epidural block:

  • Adrenaline is often included in epidural blocks. Its vasoconstrictive properties aid in reducing systemic absorption and enhancing the local anesthetic's efficacy.

Option D - Subarachnoid block:

  • Adrenaline is frequently used in subarachnoid (spinal) blocks. Similar to epidural blocks, it helps in vasoconstriction, extending the duration of the block and limiting systemic effects.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the community health center for routine immunization. The parents inquire about the correct dose of the Rotavirus vaccine being administered under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS). Which of the following is the correct dose of the Rotavirus vaccine given under NIS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5 drops:

  • Rotavirus vaccination is crucial in preventing severe diarrhea, particularly in infants and young children.
  • Adhering to the recommended dosage ensures optimal protection against Rotavirus infection and its associated complications.
  • As per the National Immunization Schedule, a total of three doses of the Rotavirus vaccine is recommended (can be given till one year of age).
    • 6 weeks
    • 10 weeks
    • 14 weeks
  • The recommended dose is 5 drops (oral).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These do not indicate the correct dosage of the Rotavirus vaccine

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the STD clinic with several painful genital ulcers, as shown in the image below. The ulcers are painful, non-indurated and drains yellow purulent discharge. On examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy present. The Gram stain of the smear from the ulcer shows Gram-negative coccobacilli. What is the most appropriate media for culture?

choices.text: Blood agar with X & V factors
Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum:

  • The clinical picture shows a soft sore (chancroid) caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection characterized by tender, non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia, spreading to the regional lymph nodes.
  • Haemophilus ducreyi is a gram-negative coccobacillus that may appear gram-positive. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a railroad track or school of fish appearance (Refer to the image below).
  • Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum, containing vancomycin as a selective agent, is used for its culture. It forms small, grey translucent colonies after incubation at 35°C under 10% CO2 and high humidity for 2-8 days.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Thayer Martin Medium:

  • Thayer martin medium is a selective medium containing antimicrobials (vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar) in chocolate agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae from clinical specimens. The antimicrobials inhibit the growth of other commensal organisms, which may inhibit the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Option B- Blood agar with X & V factors:

  • Blood agar is used to grow fastidious bacteria (Haemophilus influenzae) and differentiate them based on their hemolytic properties. It is a differential media because 3 types of hemolysis/lysis can be seen on it. It is a non-selective medium.

Option D - Tellurite blood agar:

  • It is used to isolate Corynebacterium diphtheria is a selective medium. It is selective due to the presence of inhibitors and is differentiated due to the ability of the organism to decrease potassium tellurite.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to the clinic for a consultation regarding contraception. She expressed interest in starting oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and requests information about the contents of a particular brand she saw advertised. The physician provided her with a package inserted in the image below. Based on the information provided, what is the composition of the oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg:

  • The composition of the oral contraceptive depicted in the image is Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D provide compositions that do not match the package insert shown in the image.

questions.text: An obstetrician observed an abnormality in the placental attachment during a prenatal ultrasound examination. The image below is representative of the gross specimen of the placenta seen in that presentations. Based on this, what is the most likely placental abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Battledore placenta:

  • Battledore placenta, also known as marginal cord insertion, is a condition where the umbilical cord inserts at the margin of the placenta rather than at its center.
  • This condition is generally considered benign and is often without significant clinical implications.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Velamentous Placenta:

  • Velamentous placenta is a condition where the umbilical vessels travel within the membranes (chorionic membranes) before reaching the placenta.
  • Velamentous insertion can pose risks, especially during delivery, as the unprotected vessels are more prone to rupture.

Option C - Circumvallate placenta:

  • Circumvallate placenta is a condition where the amniotic membranes fold back around the edge of the placenta.
  • This condition can be associated with complications such as preterm birth and premature rupture of membranes.

Option D - Bilobed placenta:

  • A bilobed placenta refers to a placenta that has two distinct lobes.
  • This condition is usually a variant of normal placental development and may not have significant clinical consequences.

questions.text: Preterm babies are born with thinner and less developed skin compared to full-term infants. Which of the following is a characteristic feature associated with the skin of preterm babies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Absence of Stratum Corneum:

  • Preterm babies, being born prematurely, often have underdeveloped skin, which can lead to the absence or immaturity of certain skin layers. The Stratum Corneum is the outermost layer of the epidermis and is responsible for providing a protective barrier to the skin. In preterm infants, this layer may be less developed or absent, making their skin more susceptible to fluid loss, infection, and external irritants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Absence of Stratum Basale: The Stratum Basale is the deepest layer of the epidermis, and it is responsible for cell proliferation and regeneration of the epidermal layers. It contains basal cells that continuously divide to produce new keratinocytes. The Stratum Basale is an essential layer for the renewal and repair of the epidermis. It is not typically affected in preterm babies.

Option B - Absence of Stratum Granulosum: The Stratum Granulosum is a layer of the epidermis located between the Stratum Spinosum and the Stratum Corneum. It plays a crucial role in the production of keratin and the formation of keratohyalin granules, which contribute to the skin's barrier function. While preterm babies may have less-developed Stratum Granulosum due to their premature birth, it is not specifically known for its absence

Option D - Absence of Stratum Lucidum: The Stratum Lucidum is a clear, translucent layer of the epidermis found in specific areas such as the palms and soles. While preterm babies may have less-developed Stratum Lucidum due to their premature birth, it is not specifically known for its absence

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in the decreased sensation, burning, and pins and needles sensation in the right arm's ring and little finger of the 42-year-old cyclist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Ulnar nerve

Guyon canal syndrome:

  • The case given in the question stem is Guyon canal syndrome.
  • This syndrome results due to peripheral ulnar neuropathy.
  • The neuropathy can be due to an injury involving the distal portion of the ulnar nerve.
  • The nerve root value of the ulnar nerve is C8-T1, a terminal branch of the brachial plexus.
  • The patient presents with weakness and sensory loss of the medial side of the hand involving the ring and little finger.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Radial nerve

  • The nerve compression at the axilla is due to crutches or sleeping with an arm The radial nerve palsy is caused by nerve compression at the axilla due to crutches or sleeping with an arm over the chair (Saturday night palsy); at the midshaft fracture of humerus repetitive pronation/supination of the forearm, e.g., due to screwdriver use (finger drop) or Injuries above the elbow cause loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand, wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extensions) with grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors).

Option B: Median nerve

  • Median nerve palsy is caused by Supracondylar fracture of the humerus due to a proximal nerve lesion; Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration cause distal nerve lesion.

Option C: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • It is caused by upper trunk compression, which causes decreased biceps reflex, and loss of forearm flexion and supination; also, loss of sensation occurs over the radial and dorsal forearm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. An endoscopy was performed, an image of which is given below; what is the probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mallory Weiss Tear:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking who presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood is Mallory Weiss Tear.
  • Mallory Weiss Tear is a condition characterized by a tear between the esophagus and the stomach, known as the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It is commonly associated with alcoholism and binge drinking, as well as with excessive vomiting and retching.

Incorrect Options: 

Correct Option A - Tension pneumothorax: It typically presents with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia and is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.

Option B - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome, also known as Spontaneous Esophageal Perforation, typically occurs due to forceful or repeated vomiting, predominantly affecting males.

Option D - Gastric ulcer perforation: Gastric ulcer perforation is when an ulcer in the stomach lining erodes through the stomach wall, leading to a hole or perforation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of hypertension. He reports experiencing occasional dizziness and headaches. His current medications include amlodipine 5 mg once daily. You decide to assess his blood pressure using home-based monitoring (HBPM). Which of the following statements regarding HBPM is correct?

choices.text: The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg
HBPM should be performed for 3 days, averaging both the morning and evening readings
The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded for accurate assessment
Cuff size should be 90% of arm circumference

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded for accurate assessment:

 The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded to eliminate potential measurement bias.

  • Home-based BP monitoring (HBPM) is recommended for tracking blood pressure (BP) outside of clinical settings.
  • Hypertension (HTN) is defined as BP consistently exceeding 135/85 mmHg at home.
  • HBPM involves measuring BP twice daily, in the morning and evening, for 7 days.
  • The first-day value is discarded, and the average of the remaining 6 days is calculated.
  • Proper cuff size is crucial, typically 80% of arm circumference, with width exceeding 40% of arm length.
  • Before measuring BP, individuals should rest for 5 minutes and wait 30 minutes after smoking or consuming coffee.
  • BP should be measured in both arms and legs to detect any discrepancies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg: The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >135/85 mmHg, not >140/90 mmHg.

Option B - The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg: HBPM should be performed for 7 days, both in the morning and evening, not for 3 days.

Option D -  Cuff size should be 90% of arm circumference: Cuff size should be 80% of arm circumference, not 90%.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the neurology clinic with pain upon upward gaze and a recent onset of visual disturbances. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) in the left eye. The pain is exacerbated with eye movement, particularly elevation. Further evaluation reveals a discrepancy in the nerve conduction speed between the two eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Multiple sclerosis:

  • Multiple sclerosis is a chronic inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system. It is usually seen in middle-aged women.
  • Optic neuritis is a common presenting symptom.
  • Pulfrich’s phenomenon happens when the nerve conduction speeds of the two eyes are different, and there is a discrepancy. This can lead to difficulty in stereopsis. This is experienced during daily activities like driving, catching a flight, and any such activity that needs three-dimensional vision.
  • This disease is not progressive in nature and the vision improves after some time.

Incorrect Options:
Option A – Optic neuritis:

  • Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve, often presenting with pain in eye movement, decreased visual acuity, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). While optic neuritis can occur in isolation, it is also a common symptom of multiple sclerosis.

Option B – Central retinal artery occlusion:

  • Central retinal artery occlusion typically presents with sudden painless vision loss in one eye, often described as a curtain coming down. It is not associated with pain on eye movement or a relative afferent pupillary defect

Option D – Myasthenia gravis:

  • Myasthenia gravis is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, often involving the extraocular muscles. It does not typically cause pain on eye movement or a relative afferent pupillary defect

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of low mood, decreased interest in activities, and decreased energy. He reports hearing voices that are critical of him and telling him to harm himself. He denies any history of substance abuse or previous psychiatric illness. On examination, he appears tearful, with psychomotor retardation and paranoid delusions. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

choices.text: A combination of antidepressants and antipsychotics

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with symptoms of major depressive disorder with psychotic features, as evidenced by low mood, loss of interest, decreased energy, hearing voices that are critical of him, paranoid delusions, and psychomotor retardation.
The most appropriate treatment for this condition is a combination of antidepressants and antipsychotics. Antidepressants such as SSRIs can help alleviate symptoms of depression, while antipsychotics can address psychotic symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations. This combination is considered the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder with psychotic features.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Psychotherapy alone would not be the most appropriate treatment in this case as the patient presents with severe symptoms requiring immediate intervention. 

Option B. Antidepressants alone may not be sufficient to manage the psychotic symptoms and may worsen them. 

Option C. Antipsychotics alone may be useful for addressing psychotic symptoms but may not be enough to alleviate the depressive symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for intubation before surgery. During the airway assessment, the following findings were noted: Facial trauma, Inter Incisor Distance of >3 finger breadths, Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths, Mallampati Class III, and the patient can touch his chest with his chin. What is the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the given findings:

  • Facial trauma = 1 point
  • Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point
  • Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths = 0 points
  • Mallampati Class III = 1 point
  • The patient can touch his chest with his chin = 1 point

In the Lemon Airway Classification system, points are assigned based on several parameters to predict the ease of intubation. The parameters are:

 

Look externally

facial trauma = 1 point

Evaluate 3-3-2 rule

Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point, Thyroid To Mouth Distance < 3 finger breadths = 0 points

Mallampati Class

Class III = 1 point

Obstruction or lack thereof

ability to extend the neck = 0 points

Neck mobility

ability to touch the chest with the chin = 1 point

 

Adding these points together, the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient is:

Therefore, the correct answer is C. 4 points.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with intermittent dysphagia and a sensation of a mass in her chest while swallowing. A barium swallow study is performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Leiomyoma

  • Leiomyoma is a benign tumor originating from smooth muscle cells. The esophagus typically presents as a well-defined filling defect with a smooth contour on barium swallow studies. The characteristic crescent-shaped appearance is caused by the tumor pushing against the lumen of the esophagus during swallowing.
  • First image- The lesions (arrows) have a smooth surface (etched in white) and slightly obtuse borders characteristic of submucosal masses.
  • Middle image- En face view shows a smooth, rounded filling defect in the esophagus, with splitting of barium around the lesion. The esophagus appears widened at this level.
  • Last image- The tangential view reveals the characteristic features of a submucosal lesion. The outer margin of the leiomyoma is seen as a soft tissue shadow (arrows) abutting the lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Esophageal varices: Esophageal varices are dilated veins that occur in the setting of portal hypertension. They typically appear as tortuous, serpiginous structures on barium swallow studies rather than the smooth, well-defined filling defect seen in leiomyoma.

Option C - Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal carcinoma refers to malignant tumors arising from the esophageal epithelium. It can cause irregular narrowing or strictures on barium swallow studies, but it does not typically present with the smooth, well-defined filling defect and crescent-shaped appearance seen in leiomyoma.

Option D - Zenker's diverticulum: Zenker's diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It appears as a contrast-filled pouch during barium swallow studies. It is associated with the triad of Dysphagia, Regurgitation, and Halitosis.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Drugs 
			
			
			MOA
			
		
		
			
			1. Zileuton
			
			
			a. Blocks IL-5 receptors
			
		
		
			
			2. Pranlukast
			
			
			b. Inhibits the release of inflammatory mediators
			
		
		
			
			3. Benralizumab
			
			
			c. Blocks CYSLT1 receptor of LTC4/ D4
			
		
		
			
			4. Chromoglycate
			
			
			d. Reduce the synthesis of leukotriene
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1d,2c,3a,4b:

  • Anti-inflammatory drugs (Maintenance therapy)
    • Used for chronic or persistent asthma(Mnemonic: MLoLCM)
    • Mast cell stabilizers
      • Inhibits the release of inflammatory mediators
      • Drugs are Nedocromil, Chromoglycate
    • LOX inhibitor (5-lipoxygenase inhibitor)
      • Reduce the synthesis of leukotriene
      • Drug is zileuton
      • Not used in asthma due to its hepatotoxicity property
    • Leukotriene receptor antagonist
      • Blocks CYS LT receptor of LTC4 /D4
      • Levels of LTC4 /D4 are increased
      • Recruit eosinophils
      • Drugs are Montelukast, Zafirlukast, Pranlukast
    • Corticosteroids:
      • Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs
      • DOC- Chronic or Persistent asthma
    • Monoclonal antibodies
      • Blocks IgE antibody- Omalizumab
      • Blocks IL-5- Mepolizumab, Reslizumab,
      • Blocks IL-5 receptor- Benralizumab
      • Blocks IL-4- Dupilumab

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Autopsy reports of a 45-year-old man found dead in his farmhouse, describe a wound that is approximately square-shaped and 5x5 cm by dimension. The forensic expert safely assumes that the shape of the wound indicates the weapon used, which was likely a hammer found with blood stains in the shed behind the house. Further investigation of the wound confirms that it is indeed a "fracture ala signature" In simpler terms, how would you document this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Depressed fracture:

  • When a portion of a fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as a depressed fracture.
  • It is also called ‘fracture ala signature’ (signature fracture), as the shape often points towards the shape of the offending weapon.
  • They are caused by blows from a heavy weapon having a small striking surface, such as a hammer, axe, brick or chopper.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gutter fracture:

  • A gutter fracture is formed when part of the thickness of the bone is removed so as to form a gutter, e.g. oblique bullet wounds.
  • It is usually accompanied by comminuted depressed fracture of the inner table of the skull, and the fragments causing injury to the meninges and brain.

Option C - Ring fracture:

  • Ring fracture: Fracture around the foramen magnum.
  • It is associated with falling from a height & landing on the foot.
  • All the force is transmitted from the leg and vertebral column to the base of the skull.

Option D - Sutural Fracture:

  • Sutural separation due to blow on the skull [fracture lines run along the sutural line].
  • It is also known as a diastatic fracture.
  • Most commonly seen in young adults.
  • The most common suture involved is the sagittal suture.

questions.text: A father brings his 3-month-old baby boy to the OPD because of a lack of social smile. He said that he and his wife read articles online that babies of this age should be able to smile. On examination, there are no abnormalities. The pediatrician reassured the father and advised him to wait for a specific time. What is the upper age limit at which a social smile can be attained?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 6 months:

  • The upper limit of age at which a social smile can be attained is 6 months
  • Normally it is attained at 2-3 months

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 8 months: At 8 months, the baby acquires the social skill of object permanence.

Option C: 9 months: At 9 months, the baby can wave bye-bye.

Option D: 10 months: At 10 months, the baby plays peek-a-boo.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented to the physician with complaints of severe pain around the eyes after a fall on a symmetrical surface 2 hours ago. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable. On examination of the patient, there is enophthalmos, diplopia on the upward gaze and loss of sensitivity over the cheek. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Zygomatic bone is most likely injured

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is a blow-out fracture:

  • A blow out fracture refers to a fracture of the bones surrounding the orbit (eye socket) resulting from a sudden increase in intraorbital pressure, typically due to a direct blow to the area. In this case, the patient's history of a fall on a symmetrical surface, severe eye pain, enophthalmos (sunken appearance of the eyeball), diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek are suggestive of a blowout fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maxillary fracture: Maxillary fractures typically involve the maxillary bone, which forms the upper jaw. They can occur due to trauma but are unlikely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze.

Option C - Zygomatic bone is most likely injured: The zygomatic bone, also known as the cheekbone, can be injured in trauma. However, it is less likely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze, which are more indicative of a blow-out fracture.

Option D - Frontal bone fracture: Fractures of the frontal bone, which forms the forehead, can occur due to trauma. However, they are unlikely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man who had a sternotomy for valve surgery and reported xiphodynia afterward. The joint involved is shown by the arrow marked region, belongs to which classification of joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Synchondrosis:

  • The arrow marked region is xiphi-sternal joint lying between the body of the sternum and the xiphoid process. It is structurally classified as a synchondrosis (primary cartilage joint), and functionally classified as a synarthrosis (immobile joint). It turns into synostosis (bony fusion) in old age.
  • Note: Few authors consider xiphisternal joint as a symphysis.
  • Xiphodynia represents a distinctive syndrome characterized by sternum-related pain and tenderness.

Additional information:

  • Between the ages of 15 and 29, the xiphoid process typically undergoes fusion with the body of the sternum, and turns into synostosis.
  • Ossification of the xiphoid process typically occurs around the age of 40.
  • The xiphoid process sits in the epigastric region of the abdomen and situated at the level of the 9th thoracic vertebra (T9) and corresponds to the T7 dermatome.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Symphysis:

  • Xiphi-sternal joint is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).
  • Few authors consider it as a symphysis
  • Manubrio-sternal joint is a symphysis (slightly mobile).

Option C - Syndesmosis:

  • Syndesmosis is a fibrous joint, whereas xiphisternal joint is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).

Option D - Synovial:

  • Synovial joints are freely mobile joints, whereas xiphisternal joint is an immobile joint and the type is primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).
  • Rib 2-9 have synovial joints, which are freely mobile and help in pump handle and bucket handle movement in breathing.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with a GCS of 11/15 after a fall from a roof presents with an open wound on the parietal region, inability to move his upper limb, subdural hematoma on CT brain, and fractures of C-2, C-4, C-5, and C-7 vertebrae on X-ray spine. Which vertebrae have the longest spinous process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: C-7

  • The cervical vertebrae are of two types: Typical and Atypical
  • C3, C4, C5, and C6 are the typical cervical vertebrae.
  • C1, C2, and C7 are atypical cervical vertebrae.
  • A typical cervical vertebra has a small and transversely broad body without costal facets. It has a large and triangular vertebral foramen to accommodate the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord.
  • The seventh cervical vertebra, or vertebrae prominens, is so named because it has the longest spinous process, and the process is not bifid.

Incorrect Option B, C, D:

 

  • Spinous process of C-2, C-4, C-5 is short, bifid, and inclined inferiorly.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of aspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bilateral SLN palsy:

  • Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy results in abduction of the vocal cords, leading to a high risk of aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bilateral RLN palsy: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve is not associated with an increased risk of aspiration compared to bilateral SLN palsy.

Option C - Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a moderate risk of aspiration.

Option D - Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a mild risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the migrating motor complex (MMC) is correct?

choices.text: MMC is responsible for mixing and grinding of food in the stomach.
MMC is a continuous wave of contractions that occur throughout the gastrointestinal tract.
MMC is initiated by the presence of food in the stomach.
MMC is important for preventing bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
The migrating motor complex (MMC) is a complex series of contractions that occur in the gastrointestinal tract between meals. The MMC is important for preventing bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine. 

During the quiescent phase of the MMC, the small intestine is relatively free of bacteria, allowing for the clearance of any residual undigested food and preventing bacterial overgrowth. During the MMC’s active phase, the contractions help clear out any remaining bacteria or debris that may have accumulated in the small intestine. 

Without the MMC, bacterial overgrowth is risky, leading to various gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, bloating, and abdominal pain.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. The process of mixing and grinding food in the stomach is accomplished by the process of gastric mixing, which is a separate process from the MMC. Gastric mixing involves the contraction and relaxation of the stomach muscles, which help to break down the food and mix it with digestive juices. The MMC, on the other hand, is a series of coordinated contractions that occur in the small intestine and are not involved in mixing food in the stomach.

Option B. MMC is not continuous but rather occurs cyclically. The MMC typically occurs in cycles that last for approximately 90-120 minutes and is separated by periods of relative quiescence. During the active phase of the MMC, a series of contractions begin in the stomach and then progress down through the small intestine.

Option C. While the MMC is not directly initiated by the presence of food in the stomach, it is influenced by the presence of food in the small intestine. When the small intestine is empty, the MMC is activated to clear out residual undigested food and prevent bacterial overgrowth. This means that the MMC is initiated by the absence of food in the small intestine rather than the presence of food in the stomach.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman in menopause complains of labia majora itching for 4 years. Topical medication has not helped much. She has started feeling soreness in the same area recently and washing has become uncomfortable. Examination reveals a hard lesion on the right labia with positive inguinal nodes. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid and follow up for lymph node status

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Biopsy

  • This patient's presentation is concerning for vulvar carcinoma.
  • In case of suspicion of vulvar cancer, a biopsy of the lesion is the most appropriate choice. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent type of vulvar cancer.
  • In the case of positive inguinal nodes, a CT scan or PET scan can also be done to visualize tumor size and spread.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Topical beclomethasone

  • This is used for Lichen Sclerosis
  • It is a topical steroid. It can only decrease inflammation.
  • It can’t stop or reduce cancerous growth and hence will be of no benefit to the patient.

Option B: Topical estrogen with antibiotic

  • Topical estrogen is not helpful in malignant conditions.
  • Antibiotics are beneficial in case of infection. However, since there is inguinal lymphadenopathy in a woman of advanced age with all symptoms suggestive of malignancy, we will consider it a cancerous lesion.

Option C: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid and follow-up for lymph node status

  • Due to the patient's age, long-standing history, and presentation, vulvar carcinoma. is of greater concern, and a biopsy must be performed.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism for the fever, watery diarrhea, and stomach pain in a 22-year-old male who consumed meat and presents with capsulated, non-motile, and subterminal spore arrangement in the microbiological test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clostridium perfringens:

  • This is a case of infectious diarrhoea in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, watery diarrhoea and abdominal pain.
  • In this case, infectious diarrhoea is caused by clostridium perfringens.
  • Clostridium perfringens-induced diarrhoea is caused after the ingestion of meat.

Location of spores:

  • The Clostridium perfringens have club-shaped subterminal spores.
  • Most clostridia bear sub-terminal spores except the clostridium tetani, clostridium tertium and the clostridium bifermentans.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Clostridium bifermentans:

  • Clostridium bifermentans have central and oval spores.
  • The spores are spindle-shaped.

Option C - Clostridium tetani:

  • Clostridium tetani have spherical and terminal spores.
  • These spores have a drumstick appearance.

Option D - Clostridium tertium:

  • Clostridium tertium has an oval and terminal spore.
  • These spores have a tennis racket appearance.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the community health center with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and soreness of the mouth. On examination, he has findings characteristic of vitamin B2 deficiency. Which of the following signs is NOT indicative of Vitamin B2 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Beefy red tongue:

  • Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, deficiency can manifest in various signs and symptoms, affecting mucous membranes and skin integrity.
  • A beefy red tongue typically indicates a deficiency in Vitamin B12, rather than Vitamin B2.
  • In Vitamin B12 deficiency, the tongue may appear smooth, beefy red, and sometimes sore.
  • This characteristic presentation is distinct from the changes seen in Vitamin B2 deficiency.
  • Therefore, a beefy red tongue is not a sign of Vitamin B2 deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Geographical tongue:

  • Geographical tongue, or magenta-red tongue, presents as irregular red patches on the surface of the tongue, resembling a map-like appearance due to the loss of papillae.
  • This condition is associated with multiple nutrient deficiencies, including Vitamin B2 deficiency.
  • Therefore, it can be considered a sign of Vitamin B2 deficiency.

Option B - Cheilosis:

  • Cheilosis, also known as angular cheilitis, is characterized by inflammation, redness, and fissuring at the corners of the mouth.
  • It is commonly associated with deficiencies in B vitamins, particularly riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Therefore, cheilosis is a sign of Vitamin B2 deficiency.

Option C - Angular stomatitis:

  • Angular stomatitis presents as inflammation, redness, and fissuring at the angles of the mouth.
  • It is often associated with Vitamin B2 deficiency, among other nutrient deficiencies.
  • Therefore, angular stomatitis is a sign of Vitamin B2 deficiency.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with advanced pancreatic cancer complained of chest pain for 30 minutes. ECG shows inferior wall myocardial infarction. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient does not survive. Autopsy reveals sterile non-destructive vegetations along the mitral leaflet edges. Which of the following has a similar pathogenesis to this patient's vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trousseau syndrome:

  • The patient presents with an example of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE).

  • The pathophysiology of NBTE is similar to that of Trousseau's syndrome (migratory thrombophlebitis).

  • Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) is the deposition of sterile thrombi on cardiac valves.

  • It is most likely seen with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperoestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy especially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and adenocarcinoma of the lungs (procoagulant effect of circulating mucin and tissue factor by tumours

  • It is also seen in conditions with general debility or wasting, known as marantic endocarditis.

  • The sterile valvular lesions of NBTE occur on previously normal valves and are non-destructive and small (1-5mm in diameter).

  • NBTE lesions give rise to emboli that can cause infarcts in the brain, heart, and other organs.

  • NBTE can also serve as a potential nidus for bacterial colonization and the consequent development of infective endocarditis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Hypercalcemia of malignancy:

  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy is a common finding in patients with advanced-stage cancers.

  • It presents with neuropsychiatric, gastrointestinal, renal, and bony abnormalities.

  • It does not form sterile vegetation in the valves.

Option B - Distant metastasis:

  • Cancer metastasis affects the pericardium and myocardium. It is less likely to affect cardiac valves.

  • Invasion of valves may rarely be seen in metastatic involvement

Option D - Raynaud’s phenomenon:

  • Raynaud’s phenomenon occurs due to spasm of small blood vessels in the fingers and toes.

  • It presents with skin colour changes, numbness, and sensations of pins and needles.

  • It has no link to valvular vegetations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of intermittent abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and diarrhea. On colonoscopy, multiple polyps are identified in the colon and rectum. Biopsy reveals characteristic features of juvenile polyposis syndrome. The patient has a family history of colorectal cancer. Which of the following statements regarding this sydnrome is true?

choices.text: Both juvenile polyposis syndrome and juvenile polyps have a similar risk of malignancy
The risk of malignancy is higher in juvenile polyps compared to juvenile polyposis syndrome
Juvenile polyposis syndrome has a higher risk of malignancy than juvenile polyps
Juvenile polyposis syndrome and juvenile polyps have no association with colorectal cancer.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Juvenile polyposis syndrome has a higher risk of malignancy than juvenile polyps:

  • This is because juvenile polyposis syndrome involves the presence of multiple juvenile polyps, increasing the likelihood of malignant transformation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Both juvenile polyposis syndrome and juvenile polyps have a similar risk of malignancy: This option is incorrect because, as mentioned, Above.

Option B - The risk of malignancy is higher in juvenile polyps compared to juvenile polyposis syndrome: This option is incorrect as it presents the opposite scenario.

Option D - Juvenile polyposis syndrome and juvenile polyps have no association with colorectal cancer: This option is incorrect as both juvenile polyposis syndrome and juvenile polyps are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with redness, pain, and mucopurulent discharge in the left eye. On examination, chemosis, and branched inflamed blood vessels are observed as seen in the image below. Which organism is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcus aureus:

  • In a 6-year-old child presenting with redness, pain, mucopurulent discharge, chemosis, and branched inflamed blood vessels as seen in the image the most likely diagnosis is bacterial conjunctivitis and the most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus. It is followed by Streptococcus pneumoniae which is followed by Haemophilus influenzae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptococcus pneumoniae: While Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is less commonly associated with acute bacterial conjunctivitis as compared to Staph. aureus.

Option C - Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is another common bacterium known to cause acute bacterial conjunctivitis, but it is less common than Staph. Aureus. 

Option D - Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is typically associated with severe conjunctivitis in neonates and adults exposed to sexually transmitted infections. It is less likely to be the cause in a 6-year-old child without a relevant history.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			a. When the weight for height is between -2 to -3 Z score or 70-79% of expected
			
			
			1. Severe stunting
			
		
		
			
			b. When the weight for height is < -3 Z score or <70% of expected
			
			
			2. Stunting
			
		
		
			
			c. When the height for age is between -2 to -3 Z score or 85-89% of expected
			
			
			3.Wasting
			
		
		
			
			d. When the height for age is < -3 score or < 85% of expected
			
			
			4. Severe wasting
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A-3,b-4,c-2,d-1:

  • When the weight for height is between -2 to -3 Z score or 70-79% of expected, it is known as Wasting
  • When the weight for height is < -3 Z score or <70% of expected, it is known as severe wasting
  • When the height for age is between -2 to -3 Z score or 85-89% of expected, it is known as Stunting
  • When the height for age is < -3 score or < 85% of expected, it is known as Severe stunting

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: These are not the correct matches.

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual is experiencing difficulty sleeping well at night. He frequently wakes up in the middle of the night and has trouble falling back asleep. Additionally, he feels tired and unrefreshed upon waking. There is no significant medical or psychiatric history. What type of insomnia is likely affecting this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Middle Insomnia

  • Middle Insomnia: Middle insomnia involves difficulty in maintaining sleep, where the person wakes up multiple times during the night. This matches the symptoms described in the scenario, making it the most likely type of insomnia affecting the individual.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initial Insomnia: This type of insomnia refers to difficulty initiating sleep. However, in the given scenario, the person is experiencing difficulty maintaining sleep as well, which does not match the symptoms of initial insomnia.

Option C - Late Insomnia: Late insomnia refers to early morning awakening, typically at least two hours before the usual wake-up time. While early morning awakening is mentioned in the scenario, it is not the primary complaint of the individual.

Option D - Secondary Insomnia: Secondary insomnia is caused by underlying medical or psychiatric disorders. Although the individual has no significant medical or psychiatric history mentioned in the scenario, it cannot be completely ruled out without further evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding landmarks of laparoscopic repair of indirect inguinal hernia?

choices.text: Triangle of Doom: External iliac vessels are content
Crown of death: Aberrant inferior epigastric artery
Quadrangle of Doom and pain: Triangle of Doom plus triangle of death

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Triangle of Doom: External iliac vessels are content:

  • Triangle of Doom:
    • Contents: External iliac vessels
    • It is extremely dangerous to place staples or sutures during laparoscopic hernia surgery. The "triangle of doom" is an inverted "V" shaped area with its apex at the internal (deep) inguinal ring.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Triangle of pain: Electric-friendly zone:

  • It is a hazardous electric zone.

Option C - Crown of death: Aberrant inferior epigastric artery:

  • Corona Mortis is a variant vascular anastomosis between the external iliac artery or inferior epigastric artery and obturator artery; located posterior to the superior pubic ramus, close to the quadrilateral plate of the acetabulum.

Option D - Quadrangle of Doom and pain: Triangle of Doom plus triangle of death:

  • Quadrangle of Doom and pain: Triangle of Doom plus triangle of pain.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female from India presents with symptoms of arm claudication and a significant difference in blood pressure between her left and right arms. On further evaluation, she is found to have renal artery stenosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Takayasu arteritis:

  • In this scenario, the most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis.
  • Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis commonly affecting young females, particularly from India. It is associated with ostial narrowing of the major arteries, including the renal artery, which can lead to reduced renal blood flow and hypertension.
  • Histologically, there is granulomatous thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch and proximal great vessels.
  • Clinical features:
    • Weak upper extremity pulses, blood pressure difference between left and right arms
    • Arm claudication
    • Fever, night sweats
    • Arthritis, myalgias
    • Skin nodules
    • Ocular disturbances 
  • Investigations: MR angiography is the investigation of choice, and helps stage the disease distribution. CT angiography can also be done.
  • Initial treatment of symptomatic Takayasu arteritis begins with corticosteroids.
  • Surgical revascularization is required in a few patients. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atherosclerosis of the renal artery: While atherosclerosis can cause renal artery stenosis, it typically occurs in older individuals, especially those with a history of smoking. In atherosclerosis, the entire length of the blood vessel narrows, whereas in Takayasu arteritis, only the ostium narrows.

Option B - Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD): FMD is another cause of renal artery stenosis, typically seen in young females living in the USA. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth within the arterial wall, leading to narrowing. However, in this scenario, the clinical features (arm claudication, significant blood pressure difference) and the patient's origin (India) are more suggestive of Takayasu arteritis.

Option D - Coarctation of the aorta: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by narrowing of the aorta, typically near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It causes a difference in blood pressure between the arms and legs, with higher blood pressure in the arms. However, this condition is usually diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood and is not associated with renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A healthy 35-year-old woman delivers a baby girl by a cesarean section. The pediatrician notes pallor, peripheral cyanosis, and cold extremities on immediate examination. The baby is placed under a radiant warmer to address hypothermia. What is the mechanism of maximum heat production in babies placed in this warmer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - :Radiation

  • Radiant warmer: It is an open care system and there is an overhead heating unit which consists of quartz crystal.
  • It is readily available, less expensive and should be used in care of all babies with hypothermia.
  • Most important mode of heating: Radiation
  • Heat loss mainly takes place through Convection

Incorrect Options:

Option A, D & C - Evaporation / Convection & Conduction: These are not mechanisms of a radiant warmer for production of maximum heat in a baby placed in it

questions.text: What is the optimal management for two 4 x 5 cm subserosal fibroids on the uterine fundus that have failed to respond to medical therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Myomectomy

  • Myomectomy is a surgical procedure to remove fibroids while preserving the uterus. It is a suitable option for women with symptomatic fibroids who desire fertility or wish to keep their uterus. There are different types of myomectomy, including laparoscopic myomectomy and hysteroscopic myomectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Hysterectomy

  • Hysterectomy involves the complete removal of the uterus. It is a definitive treatment for fibroids and is often considered when fertility is not a concern or when other conservative treatments have failed. It eliminates the possibility of future pregnancies.

Option B: Endometrial Ablation

  • Endometrial ablation is a procedure that destroys the lining of the uterus (endometrium) and is typically used to treat abnormal uterine bleeding. It is not a treatment for fibroids and does not remove the fibroids themselves.

Option D: Uterine artery embolization (UAE)

  • Big fibroids, submucous fibroids, and calcified fibroids are not suited for UAE
  • Uterine artery embolization is a minimally invasive procedure to manage uterine fibroids.
  • It consists of embolization of the uterine artery and vessels feeding the fibroid with PVC particles under fluoroscopy guidance, which ultimately causes shrinkage of fibroids and relief in menorrhagia
  • Uterine embolization may result in compromised blood flow later and may be associated with infertility and placental insufficiency in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the clinic complaining of a dry, productive cough with rusty-coloured sputum, fever, and chills for 4 days. Respiratory examination revealed tachypnea with dullness to percussion in the left lower lobe. The CURB-65 is used to assess the severity of this patient. Which of the following is not associated with CURB 65?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C - SBP > 90 mmHg

  • CURB-65 is a severity score to predict mortality in community-acquired pneumonia
  • CURB-65 criteria:
    • C - Confusion
    • U - BUN >7 mmol/L (>19 mg/dL)
    • R - > 30/min
    • B - BP = Systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic < 60 mmHg
    • 65 - Age > 65 years

Incorrect options: A, B and D - Refer to the above explanation

questions.text: Which medication is used to prevent the action of growth hormone at its receptors in the treatment of acromegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pegvisomant:

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to prevent the action of growth hormone at its receptors in the treatment of acromegaly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Octreotide: Octreotide inhibits growth hormone secretion from the pituitary gland but does not directly block its action at its receptors.

Option C - Somatostatin: Somatostatin and analogs like octreotide reduce growth hormone secretion but do not directly block its action at its receptors.

Option D - Bromocriptine: Bromocriptine inhibits growth hormone secretion but does not directly block its action at its receptors like pegvisomant.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with advanced corneal disease requires a corneal transplant. Which type of keratoplasty would involve replacing the full thickness of the cornea with a healthy cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Penetrating keratoplasty:

  • Penetrating keratoplasty (PK) involves the replacement of the full thickness of the cornea with a healthy cornea. It is the standard surgical procedure for corneal transplantation. Donor cornea is placed onto the recipient's cornea, and the edges are sutured together.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lamellar keratoplasty: Lamellar keratoplasty involves the replacement of partial thickness of the cornea, while preserving the endothelium. It is of two types : Anterior and Posterior.

  • Anterior lamellar keratoplasty:
    • It is the replacement of the anterior portion of the cornea without disturbing the endothelium, as there is a high chance of endothelium graft rejection.
  • Posterior lamellar/ Deep endothelial lamellar keratoplasty:
    • This type replaces the endothelium with or without a part of the stroma.

Option C - Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty: Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) is a variation of lamellar keratoplasty that involves the removal of the anterior layers of the cornea, including the diseased or scarred tissue, while preserving the healthy endothelium. It is mainly used in cases where the disease or damage is limited to the front part of the cornea.

Option D - Endothelial keratoplasty: Endothelial keratoplasty, also known as Descemet's stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK) or Descemet's membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK), involves the transplantation of only the endothelial layer of the cornea. It is performed for conditions where the endothelial cells are dysfunctional, such as Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy or corneal endothelial cell loss.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman recently diagnosed with carcinoma of the endometrium is getting staging laparotomy including a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. During laparotomy, it was found that her superficial inguinal lymph nodes were also positive. This can be classified as which stage of endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: 4

  • Inguinal lymph node involvement is important in all gynecological cancers.
 

Carcinoma of The Endometrium Staging

Stage 1*

Tumour confined to the corpus uteri

IA *

No or less than half of myometrial invasion

IB *

Invasion equal to or more than half of the myometrium

Stage II *

Tumour invades cervical stoma, but does not extend beyond the uterus **

Stage III *

Local and/or regional spread of the tumor

IIIA *

Tumour invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexa#

IIIB *

Vaginal and/or parametrial involvement #

IIIC *

Metastases to pelvic and /or para-aortic lymph nodes #

IIIC1 *

Positive pelvic nodes

IIIC2 *

Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes

Stage IV *

Tumour invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa, and /or distant metastases

IVA *

Tumor invasion of bladder and/or bowel mucosa

IVB *

Distant metastases, including intra-abdominal metastases and/or inguinal lymph nodes

Option A: 1

  • This option is incorrect because stage 1 means the tumor is confined to the uterine body.

Option B: 2

  • This option is incorrect because stage 2 endometrial carcinoma is the tumor invading the cervix.

Option C: 3

  • This option is incorrect because, in stage 3, the tumor invades the parametrium and metastases of pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes. In contrast, superficial inguinal lymph node metastases are considered distant metastases.

questions.text: A rapid diagnostic test is designed based on the principle of the Immunochromatography Test (ICT) for the detection of a specific analyte in a blood sample. The blood sample passes through a nitrocellulose membrane during the test. What is the primary purpose of the control line in this rapid diagnostic test?

choices.text: To indicate the presence of the analyte in the sample
To confirm the validity of the test procedure
To enhance the visibility of the test line
To differentiate between positive and negative reactions.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To confirm the validity of the test procedure:

  • The control line serves as a built-in validation mechanism for the test procedure. The control line is always present on the test strip and serves as an indicator that the test has been performed correctly and the components of the test strip are functioning as intended.
  • When a blood sample is applied and flows through the test strip, the presence of a visible control line confirms that the sample has moved through the membrane and the test is valid.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To indicate the presence of the analyte in the sample: The presence of the analyte is typically indicated by the appearance of a visible line at the test line, not the control line.

Option C - To enhance the visibility of the test line: The control line does not directly affect the visibility of the test line.

Option D - To differentiate between positive and negative reactions: The differentiation between positive and negative reactions is typically determined by the appearance of a visible line at the test line, not the control line.

questions.text: A term 10-week-old male baby was brought to the clinic complaining of not gaining weight adequately. On examination by the Pediatrician, Tachypnea and tachycardia were present. On auscultation, a continuous machinery murmur was found. Chest X-ray was advised, and the report showed Cardiomegaly with LV apex. What is the drug of choice for this condition in preterm neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Indomethacin:

  • This is the drug of choice used for the closure of Patent ductus arteriosus in preterm neonates
  • It is a prostaglandin inhibitor
  • The condition described in the question is Patent ductus arteriosus
  • It is characterized by failure to thrive, tachypnea, tachycardia, and a continuous machinery murmur on auscultation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aspirin

Option C - Digoxin

Option D - Furosemide

  • These are not the drugs of choice for closure of Patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 47-year-old female working as a staff nurse in a local primary health center was referred to a hospital with a one-month history of continuous abdominal pain and distension, fever, night sweats, and significant weight loss. An abdominal examination revealed no organomegaly. Barium meal follow-through was done. Which of the following radiological signs is seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - String sign of Kantor:

  • Barium study showed persistent narrowing due to stricture formation, also called the string sign of Kantor. This sign is seen in gastrointestinal tuberculosis as well as Crohn’s disease. Considering the likelihood of an infectious cause and the radiographic sign, the diagnosis is gastrointestinal tuberculosis.
  • Barium meal follow-through is a diagnostic procedure used for the diagnosis of many diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. On barium meal follow-through In tuberculosis, the following findings can be seen:
    • Contraction of the mesocolon
    • Pulled-up cecum
    • Obtuse ileocecal angle
    • Gooseneck deformity
    • Stierlin sign: The rapid uptake of barium into the colon due to the formation of transverse ulcers in the ileum causes hyper-irritability. This results in a narrowed appearance of the ileum.
    • Persistent narrowing due to strictures results in a string sign of Kantor.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gooseneck appearance:

  • This is a feature of gastrointestinal tuberculosis affecting the ileum.
  • The dilated terminal ileum appears to be hanging from a retracted cecum, resulting in a gooseneck appearance.

Option C - Fleischner's sign:

  • This is a sign of ileocecal tuberculosis.
  • Thickening of ileocecal valve lips and wide gaping of the valve with narrowing of the terminal ileum results in an inverted umbrella sign or Fleischner's sign.

Option D - Umbrella sign:

  • The umbrella sign is found in long-standing cases of gastrointestinal tuberculosis.
  • The thickened ileocecal valve, rigid cecum, and narrowed ileum are umbrella signs.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, who has positive urine pregnancy test, develops acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, she is drowsy, her blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 120 per minute. Which of the following is the most suitable treatment option in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • The above history of a pregnant woman with acute pain abdomen, and vaginal bleeding with signs of shock is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic. with hemodynamic instability. The management of this case is immediate laparotomy. Laparoscopy should be employed only when the patient is hemodynamically stable.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Laparoscopic salpingectomy is the treatment of choice in case of ruptured tubal ectopic. However, the patient should be hemodynamically stable, or a laparotomy is preferred due to the need for quick intervention to arrest the bleeding.

Option C: Culdocentesis is a method in which fluid from pouch of douglas is aspirated, presence of non-clotting blood is suggestive of ruptured ectopic pregnancy when other signs are suggestive, however this is not diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy.

Option D: Resuscitation must be done for all cases but in this case, it has to be followed up with immediate surgery to stop the bleeding.

questions.text: Nissl's body is an aggregate of rough endoplasmic reticulum and free ribosomes, which of the following is not true regarding Nissl’s body?

choices.text: The highest density is found in motor neurons
They are rich in RNA material

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – They are eosinophilic in nature:

  • Nissl bodies are basophilic, not eosinophilic. They stain blue or purple when using basic dyes like methylene blue or hematoxylin due to their high RNA content, which binds to these dyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – The highestdensity is found in motor neurons: This statement is true. Nissl bodies have the highest density in motor neurons, which are metabolically very active and require substantial protein synthesis.

Option C – Never found in axonal cytoplasm: This statement is true. Nissl bodies are primarily found in the cell body or soma of neurons and are absent in the axonal cytoplasm.

Option D – They are rich in RNA material: This statement is true. Nissl bodies consist of aggregated rough endoplasmic reticulum and free ribosomes, which are rich in RNA.

questions.text: What's the most likely mutation in a 27-year-old male with recurrent abdominal pain, dark, tarry stools, and hyperpigmented macules on lips, buccal mucosa, and perioral region, with a family history of similar skin findings in the father, and a jejunal polyp on endoscopy with the following histological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  - Option- C) STK11 gene:

  • This image is a histology of the jejunal polyp and it shows arborizing bundles of smooth muscle surrounded by small intestinal glandular epithelium.

    The clinical presentation of recurrent abdominal pain, dark tarry stools, and the presence of hamartomatous polyps in the jejunum with characteristic histology, along with the mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, is consistent with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

    Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is caused by mutations in the serine/threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene, also known as LKB1. This gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in STK11 are associated with the development of hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, as well as mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Incorrect Options: 

The other options (A) TSC1 gene, (B) PTEN gene, and (D) APC gene are associated with different genetic syndromes:

  • TSC1 gene is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
  • PTEN gene is associated with Cowden syndrome.
  • APC gene is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

questions.text: What is your diagnosis for a 10-year-old child based on the observed clinical findings, as depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tram line bruise:

  • The image shows 'tram line' bruising most likely to have been produced by a stick or a broom handle.
  • When a person is hit with a stick, a line bruise is produced
  • They are also known as railway line bruises

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ectopic bruise:

  • Bruise away from the site of impact.
  • Eg: Battle's sign, in a case of middle cranial fossa fracture

Option C - Six penny bruises:

  • It is seen in manual strangulation (Throttling) i.e. compression of the neck by hand of the assailant.

Option D - Butterfly bruise:

  • It is produced by skin pinching; seen in child abuse.

questions.text: All are true about the Sabin vaccine except?

choices.text: It is a live attenuated vaccine
The mode of administration is via the oral route
It required sub-zero temperatures for storage and transport

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The shelf life is longer:

  • This is incorrect about the Sabin vaccine
  • The shelf life is shorter for the Sabin vaccine
  • The shelf life is longerfor the Salk vaccine

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, D:

  • These are the correct characteristics of the Sabin vaccine

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Screening

			a. Anomaly scan

			b. NT scan
			
			
			2)12 weeks
			
		
		
			
			c. Triple marker test

Correct Option A - a-3,b-2,c-1:

  • NT scan is done at 12 weeks
