questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the poisoning caused by the seeds shown below?

choices.text: Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning
Inhibits neurotransmitter glycine effect at the pre-synaptic receptor

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine effect at pre-synaptic receptor:

  • The above given image is of Strychnine Seeds aka Dog Buttons
  • It is used to kill stray dogs, hence called Dog-buttons.
    • Seeds shape is concavo-convex.
    • It is odorless and bitter in taste.
    • Fatal dose: One crushed seed
  • Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine which does not effect the pre synaptic receptor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pleurosthotonus:

  • Pleurosthotonus: Lateral flexion of the spine, which is a feature of Strychnine poisoning.

Option B - Post mortem caloricity:

  • After death ‘Postmortem caloricity’ phenomenon occurs i.e., initially after death, the patient remains warm for few hours.

Option C - Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning:

  • Unbroken seeds when ingested are not poisonous, as the hard pericarp is not soluble in digestive juices.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a complaint of itchy skin in her underarms and around her nipples. On examination, small, skin-colored to yellowish papules are observed in the affected areas. The patient reports that the condition worsens during periods of increased sweat production. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fox-Fordyce disease:

  • Fox-Fordyce disease is a rare skin condition that presents with small, skin-colored to yellowish papules in areas with apocrine sweat glands, such as the underarms, nipples, and genital region. The condition is associated with blockage of the apocrine ducts, leading to inflammation and the formation of the characteristic papules. Itching is a common symptom, and the condition can worsen during periods of increased sweat production. Gender predilection, 90% cases in females

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hidradenitis suppurativa:

  • Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that affects the hair follicles and apocrine sweat glands. It presents with painful, inflamed nodules and abscesses, which can lead to the formation of tunnels and scarring. Unlike Fox-Fordyce disease, hidradenitis suppurativa is associated with more significant inflammation and suppuration.

Option C - Psoriasis:

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by raised, red patches with silvery scales. It typically occurs on the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. Psoriasis is not directly related to apocrine sweat glands and does not present with small, yellowish papules as seen in Fox-Fordyce disease.

Option D - Contact dermatitis: 

  • Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction caused by exposure to allergens or irritants. It leads to red, itchy, and sometimes blistered skin. While it can occur in various body regions, it is not specifically associated with apocrine sweat gland areas and does not present with small, skin-colored to yellowish papules like Fox-Fordyce disease.

questions.text: BERA is performed to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. Which wave in Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is typically the largest, most stable, and considered the most significant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Wave V

  • This wave is produced from the lateral lemniscus and is observed around 5.5 ms.
  • Wave V is typically the largest, tallest, most stable, and considered the most significant wave in BERA.
  • It represents the neural activity occurring at the level of the lateral lemniscus, which is involved in the transmission of auditory information to higher auditory centers in the brain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wave I:

  • This wave is produced by the distal part of the Eighth nerve and occurs at approximately 1.5 milliseconds (ms) after the auditory stimulus. It represents the initial electrical activity generated by the auditory nerve.

Option B - Wave III:

  • This wave is produced from the cochlear nucleus and appears at around 3.5 ms. It represents the processing of auditory information in the brainstem at the level of the cochlear nucleus.

Option C - Wave IV:

  • This wave is generated from the superior olivary complex and is typically observed at approximately 4.5 ms. It reflects the neural activity occurring at the level of the superior olivary complex, which plays a role in sound localization and binaural processing.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents to the OPD with a painless swelling below the inner corner of the right eye that has been present since birth. On examination, a bluish cystic mass is noted, and gentle pressure causes regurgitation of mucoid material. What embryological structure is involved in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Imperforated Hasner Valve:

  • This clinical presentation is indicative of a congenital dacryocele, where there is dilation of the lacrimal sac due to an imperforated Hasner valve. The Hasner valve is a membrane at the inferior end of the nasolacrimal duct, and an imperforated valve can result in the retention of amniotic fluid mucus trapping in the lacrimal sac.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Failure of nasolacrimal duct canalization:

  • Failure of nasolacrimal duct canalization typically leads to nasolacrimal duct obstruction and epiphora, not a bluish cystic mass.

Option B - Abnormal lacrimal puncta formation:

  • Lacrimal puncta are responsible for draining tears into the nasolacrimal duct, and abnormal formation could contribute to tear drainage issues, but it doesn't directly match the described presentation.

Option D - Aberrant lacrimal gland development:

  • Aberrant lacrimal gland development is not typically associated with the described presentation of a bluish cystic mass below the inner corner of the eye with mucoid material regurgitation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol consumption presents with confusion and lethargy. Crackles and wheezes are noted on the right side of the chest, raising suspicion of aspiration. Which of the following features does not favor aspiration into the right bronchus?

choices.text: Has more chances of foreign body lodging

questions.solution:
Option D: More horizontal

  • The patient presenting with an altered state of consciousness (Confusion, not oriented to time and place) with examination findings of crackles and wheezes in the right lung has aspirated due to alcohol-induced sedation.
  • The aspiration most commonly occurs on the right side.
  • One of the reasons for right-sided aspiration is the angle of the right principle bronchus with the trachea
  • The right principal bronchus is more vertical, not horizontal, favoring aspiration.

Option A: Short in length

  • The short length of the right-sided bronchus is one of the factors responsible for aspiration

Option B: Has wide lumen

  • Right principle bronchus has a wide lumen. Hence, right-sided aspiration is more common

Option C: Has more chances of foreign body lodging

  • Foreign body is more commonly lodged in the right-sided bronchus as it is more vertical.

questions.text: A survey is conducted in a rural community with a total population of 11,000 a survey is conducted to assess contraceptive prevalence rates (CPR) as part of a family planning program. The current total fertility rate (TFR) is 3.4. The community health team aims to achieve a net reproduction rate (NRR) of one to maintain population stability. Which among the following is the contraceptive prevalence rate required to attain an NRR of one?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - > 60%:

  • A contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) of greater than 60% is required to attain a net reproduction rate (NRR) of one. This level of contraceptive usage indicates a relatively high proportion of the population using contraception, leading to a decrease in the total fertility rate (TFR) and subsequently lowering the NRR. Achieving an NRR of one is essential for maintaining population stability.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - >40%:

  • It suggests a lower threshold (40%), which may not be sufficient to stabilize the population growth.

Option C - >70%:

  • It suggests a higher threshold (70%), which is unnecessary as an NRR of one can be achieved with a CPR of greater than 60%.

Option D - <70%:

  • It suggests a range without a clear threshold, making it less precise in determining the target CPR needed for population stability.

questions.text: Which among the following best describes the 'Wartenberg sign'?

choices.text: Inability to adduct a small finger against the ring finger
Inability to flex the middle finger
Inability to maintain intrinsic plus position

questions.solution:
Option A: Inability to adduct a small finger against the ring finger

  • Wartenberg's sign/test is used for assessing the integrity of the motor innervations of hand intrinsics in cases of suspected ulnar neuropathy. It refers to the slightly greater abduction of the fifth digit. It is due to weakness or paralysis of the adducting palmar interosseous muscle and also due to the unopposed action of the radial innervated extensor muscles, e.g., digiti mini, digitorum communis
  • It should not be confused with Waardenburg syndrome; it is an entrapment of the superficial branch of the radial nerve; it only manifests with sensory abnormalities and no motor deficits.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Inability to extend the wrist

  • This patient's radial nerve is intact to extend his wrist.

Option C: Inability to flex the middle finger

  • The median nerve mainly Supplies the flexors of a middle finger, so flexion of the middle fingers would be intact in this patient.

Option D: Inability to maintain intrinsic plus position

  • The intrinsic plus position is the position in which MCP joints are Flexed at 60°, the IP joints are fully extended, the thumb is in the first position, and the wrist is held in an extended position.
  • An ulnar nerve palsy doesn't affect the position.

questions.text: The red nucleus inhibits the activity of the antigravity muscles and facilitates the activity of the flexor muscles, lie at the level of
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Midbrain Superior colliculus:

  • The red nucleus (RN) is located in the upper midbrain on the ventral (tegmentum) aspect.
  • Note: The superior colliculus is also located in the rostral (upper/superior) midbrain, but on the dorsal (tectum) aspect.
  • The red nucleus and substantia nigra are subcortical centers of the extrapyramidal motor system, for controlling motor activity.

Incorrect Opions:

Option A - Midbrain inferior colliculus:

  • The red nucleus is present at the level of the superior colliculus, not the inferior colliculus.

Option C - Pons:

  • The red nucleus is situated in the tegmentum of the midbrain and not in the pons.
  • This option is incorrect

Option D - Medulla oblongata:

  • The red nucleus is situated in the tegmentum of the midbrain and not in the Medulla oblongata.

questions.text: Which of the following are not considered examples of anticipatory control systems?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Adaptive relaxation of the stomach:

  • Adaptive relaxation occurs as a response to the filling of the stomach, allowing it to accommodate larger volumes of food. It is more reactive and not strictly anticipatory.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Thermoregulation System: Thermoregulation involves maintaining body temperature within a narrow range. This can include anticipatory mechanisms, such as sweating before physical activity in anticipation of increased heat production. 

Option B – Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is a preparatory phase that occurs before food enters the stomach. It involves the release of digestive enzymes and stomach acid in response to sensory stimuli (sight, smell, taste of food). This is an example of anticipatory control, preparing the digestive system for food intake.

Option C – Receptive relaxation of the stomach: Receptive relaxation occurs in response to the arrival of food in the mouth on swallowing food, and it enters the upper parts of the esophagus, the upper part of the stomach relaxes or dilates. This happens ahead of the food reaches, in order to receive the food.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to a primary health care center with hypopigmented patches on his skin. After a thorough examination, the primary care physician diagnoses him with leprosy without any disability. The physician refers the patient to the nearest designated health facility for further management. Assuming an ASHA worker facilitated this case detection, how much incentive is typically provided to the ASHA worker in such cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rs:250:

  • This is the correct answer.
  • ASHA workers typically receive Rs. 250 as an incentive for detecting cases of leprosy without disability.
  • This amount is specified by the government as part of the incentive structure for various health interventions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rs. 200:

  • This is incorrect.
  • ASHA workers typically receive Rs. 200 as an incentive for detecting cases of leprosy with disability.

Option C - Rs. 300:

  • This option is incorrect.
  • While Rs. 300 might appear attractive, it is not the standard incentive given to ASHA workers for detecting cases of leprosy without disability.

Option D - Rs. 350:

  • This option is incorrect.
  • Although Rs. 350 seems like a significant incentive, it is not the typical amount provided to ASHA workers for detecting cases of leprosy without disability.

questions.text: A child is presented with pale skin and blonde hair. His pedigree is given below. Identify the type of given pedigree.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Autosomal recessive: 

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, the disorder typically appears in individuals who have two copies of the defective gene (homozygous) or in individuals who inherit one defective gene from each parent (heterozygous).
  • This means that both parents are typically unaffected carriers of the disorder, and the disorder may skip generations before appearing.
  • The pedigree given here shows the characteristic features of autosomal recessive inheritance:
    • Affected individuals usually have unaffected parents.
    • Consanguinity (relatedness between parents) is more common in autosomal recessive disorders because both parents carry the same recessive allele.
    • Both males and females are affected with equal frequency.
    • Affected individuals may have siblings who are also affected.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - X-linked recessive:

  • X-linked recessive disorders typically show a pattern where affected males are more common than affected females, as males only have one X chromosome, and if it carries the defective gene, they will manifest the disorder.
  • In the given pedigree, there is no clear pattern of affected males being more common.

Option B - Autosomal dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant disorders usually have affected individuals in every generation, as only one copy of the defective gene is needed for the disorder to manifest.
  • In the given pedigree, there are unaffected parents who have an affected child, which is not characteristic of autosomal dominant inheritance.

Option C - X-linked dominant:

  • X-linked dominant disorders typically affect more females than males, as females have two X chromosomes, and if one carries the defective gene, they are more likely to manifest the disorder.
  • In the given pedigree, there is no clear pattern of more affected females than males.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is diagnosed with a deficiency in a specific receptor responsible for the uptake of globulin proteins. As a result, there is impaired cellular internalization of these macromolecules, affecting their transport within the cell. Which cellular process is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Clathrin-mediated endocytosis:

  • In this scenario, where a specific receptor responsible for the uptake of globulin proteins is deficient and cellular internalization is impaired, clathrin-mediated endocytosis is primarily affected.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Phagocytosis: Phagocytosis is the process of engulfing large particles or microorganisms and is not associated with the uptake of specific proteins like globulin.

Option B – Pinocytosis: Pinocytosis is the nonspecific uptake of small droplets of extracellular fluid and does not involve the specific uptake of globulin proteins.

Option D – Exocytosis: Exocytosis is the process of releasing substances from intracellular vesicles into the extracellular space and is not related to the impaired uptake of globulin proteins.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - GM 1 Ganglioside Receptor:

  • The presence of rice water stools suggests the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae.
  • Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which is coded by the CTx gene, and it is bipartite.
  • Cholera toxin has 2 fragments, A and B.
  • Fragment B has 5 subunits responsible for the attachment to the jejunal epithelial cells through GM 1 ganglioside.
  • Fragment A has 2 subunits, A1 and A2. A2 fragments link the active subunit A1 with the B fragment. Fragment A1 is biologically active subunit responsible for toxic effect,
    • Activate adenyl ate cyclase.
    • Phosphorylation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane protein.
    • Ions secreted in lumen, responsible for rice water stools.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: A diagnosed case of ADHD presented to OPD with tics. Which among the following drugs is given to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Guanfacine:

  • Guanfacine is alpha 2 adrenergic agonist.
  • It is used in the treatment of ADHD children along with tics.
  • Other drugs used are
    • Clonidine
    • Atomoxetine
  • These drugs are Non-stimulant drugs.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Methylphenidate:

  • It is Norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitors
  • DOC for Attention Deficit Hyperkinetic Disorder.
  • It increases the level of Catecholamines in the brain.

Option C, D - Dexamphetamine, Dextroamphetamine:

  • These are Amphetamines that are approved for the treatment of ADHD.
  • These drugs increase attention span and improve academic performance
  • These are stimulant drugs and cause Hyperkinesia (Tics occur) due to increased sympathetic activity.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a young female patient with iron deficiency anemia is shown below. Identify the cell labeled in this smear.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Basophil:

  • The labeled cell in this patient’s smear is a basophil.
  • Reactive basophilia is sometimes seen in iron deficiency anemia.
  • Basophils are the least common granulocytes in the blood, making up less than 1% of all circulating leukocytes.
  • Basophils stain purple with dense blue cytoplasmic granules overlaying and almost obscuring the nucleus.
  • They have a role in allergic reactions and helminth infestations.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is most likely present at the site marked as C in the diagram of 1st rib given below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Scalenus anterior

  •  The site marked as C in the diagram shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle. The upper surface of the shaft of the first rib is crossed obliquely by two grooves separated by a ridge. The ridge is enlarged at the inner border of the rib to form a scalene tubercle. The anterior groove on the superior surface of the shaft lodges the subclavian vein(D), and the posterior groove lodges the subclavian artery(B) and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. Behind the groove for the subclavian artery is an elongated rough area where the middle scalene(A) inserts.
  • The anterior scalene muscle lies beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It originates from the anterior tubercles of transverse processes of C3-C6 vertebrae and attaches to the scalene tubercle present on the medial side of the first rib. Its tendon is sandwiched between the subclavian vein (passing anteriorly) and subclavian artery (passing posteriorly). Both vessels cross over the superior surface of the 1st rib. It elevates the first rib, ipsilateral lateral flexion of the neck and bilateral anterior flexion of the neck and is innervated by the anterior rami of the C5 and C6 vertebrae. The interscalene block is given between the anterior and middle scalene muscles at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Option D: Subclavian vein

  • The site marked as D shows the groove for the subclavian vein. It is an anterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option B: Subclavian artery

  • The site marked as B shows the groove for the subclavian artery. It is a posterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. It lodges the subclavian artery and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option A: Scalenus medius

  • The site marked as A shows an elongated rough area behind the groove for the subclavian artery. It is the site attachment of the middle scalene muscle. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with mucosal bleeding, nasal obstruction, and mild breathing difficulty for over two weeks. Physical examination reveals swelling at the left part of the nose and painless lymph node enlargement over 5 cm in diameter. Skin biopsy shows macrophages containing amastigotes as ovoid inclusions microscopically, leading to a diagnosis of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. What is the causative agent for this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leishmania braziliensis:

  • Mucosal Leishmaniasis is a form of tegumentary Leishmaniasis, which is most likely associated with L.braziliensis and L.panamensis.
  • Classically it is characterized by well-defined ulcers with elevated borders.
  • Lymph node enlargement is usually painless or mildly painful, found in the groin, the crural region and least likely in the popliteal region.
  • Most of the ulcers caused by L.braziliensis are located in the lower limb region.
  • In L.braziliensis transmission regions, about 3% of cutaneous leishmaniasis patients, after disease remission, develop a mucosal form of the disease called espundia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - L. Tropica:

  • It causes cutaneous Leishmaniasis and results in non-ulcerating lesions.
  • Mostly found in Asia and Africa.

Option C - L. donovani:

  • It causes Visceral Leishmaniasis, also known as Kala-azar (black fever).
  • It usually presents with flu-like symptoms, spiking fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, edema, pancytopenia and darkened skin.
  • Amphotericin B is preferred monotherapy.

Option D - L. orientalis:

  • A parasite from Thailand responsible for localized cutaneous Leishmaniasis.

questions.text:
A recent outbreak of dengue fever has been reported in a densely populated urban area. As part of the public health response, vector control measures are being implemented. Match the following mosquitoes with their most likely breeding sites.


	
		
			
			Insects
			
			
			Breeding places
			
		
		
			
			1. Anopheles
			
			
			a. Dirty, polluted water
			
		
		
			
			2. Culex
			
			
			b. Artificially collected water
			
		
		
			
			3. Aedes
			
			
			c. Clean, stagnant water
			
		
		
			
			4. Mansonia
			
			
			d. Large water bodies with aquatic plantations
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-c,2-a,3-b,4-d:

  1. Anopheles, the primary vector for malaria, prefers breeding sites with stagnant water bodies, such as ponds and marshes.
  2. Culex, the vector for diseases like West Nile virus, Japanese encephalitis, and lymphatic filariasis, commonly breeds in dirty and polluted water sources such as drains, septic tanks, and sewage systems.
  3. Aedes aegypti, the primary vector for dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever, typically breeds in artificially collected water like flower pots, buckets, and discarded tires.
  4. Mansonia, the vector for Brugia malayi, prefers large water bodies with aquatic plants such as lakes.

Incorrect Options

Option B - 1-a,2-c,3-d,4-b

Option C - 1-d,2-a,3-b,4-c

Option D - 1-c,2-d,3-a,4-b

  • These do not indicate the correct matches between the mosquitoes and their breeding sites.

Match the following appropriately

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of rectal prolapse. On examination, it is observed that the prolapse involves the full thickness of the rectum. The patient reports difficulty tolerating long-duration surgeries. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Rectopexy with mesh fixation to the sacrum

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anal wiring:

  • Anal wiring is a management option for rectal prolapse in patients who cannot tolerate long-duration surgeries. In anal wiring, the anal canal is narrowed to prevent the rectum from prolapsing. This is a less invasive procedure compared to rectopexy or resection rectopexy and may be suitable for patients with difficulty tolerating extensive surgeries.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A , B & D are incorred as explained in LO

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true for a patient with hematuria and the given renal histopathology slide?



1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4, and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show flea-bitten appearance.

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1,2 and 3 are true:

The image shows hypercellular glomerulus, increased inflammatory (neutrophilic) infiltrate, proliferative changes in endothelium and mesangial cells

The likely diagnosis in this patient is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex mediated)

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4 and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show a flea-bitten appearance.

These statements are true regarding PSGN.

questions.text: What is the cause of earache in a patient with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing, and what are the given examination findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Irritation of glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • The given clinical findings are suggestive of acute tonsilitis. The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) innervates the tonsillar bed and gives rise to a plexus known as the tympanic plexus, extending into the middle ear. Irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve due to tonsillitis can lead to referred otalgia or ear pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Middle ear infections:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not middle ear infections.

Option B - Irritation of vagus nerve:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not by the vagus nerve.

Option D - Eustachian tube blockage:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not Eustachian tube dysfunction.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate diagnosis for a 54-year-old woman presenting with fever, weight loss, fatigue, petechiae, clubbing of fingers, and subsequent massive stroke leading to death, with an autopsy revealing the given mitral valve pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bacterial endocarditis:

  • In this case, the mitral valve has destructive vegetation that has been eroded through the free edges of the valve leaflets.

  • Vegetations in bacterial endocarditis form on the atrial side of the atrioventricular valves and the ventricular side of the semilunar valves, often at the occlusion points of the cusps or cusps.

  • They are made up of platelets, fibrin, cell debris, and masses of organisms.

  • The underlying valve tissue is damaged, so the leaflet is perforated and regurgitated.

  • The disease begins with nonspecific symptoms such as low fever, fatigue, anorexia, and weight loss.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Carcinoid heart disease:

  • Carcinoid heart disease affects the right side of the heart and causes tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary stenosis.

  • It occurs in the advanced form of carcinoid syndrome.

  • This syndrome occurs due to a carcinoid tumor that secretes serotonin and other chemicals into the bloodstream.

  • It involves the right-sided heart walls and eventually leads to right heart failure.

Option C - Libman-Sacks endocarditis:

  • Libman-sacks endocarditis is a form of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis.

  • It most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves.

  • The vegetation has the following characteristics:

    • Small and firm

    • Friable

    • Tan masses

    • Broad base

  • The lesions are small (1 to 4 mm in diameter), single or multiple, sterile, pink vegetations with a warty (verrucous) appearance.

  • They may be located on the undersurfaces of the atrioventricular valves, on the valvular endocardium, on the chords, or on the mural endocardium of the atria or ventricles.

  • Vegetations are small, sterile, and firm and commonly affect the valve's lower surface.

  • Hypercoagulable states are the usual precursor to NBTE.

  • These include APLA syndrome, SLE, chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy, particularly mucinous adenocarcinomas.

Option D - Mitral valve prolapse:

  • Mitral valve prolapse and congenital heart defects are the most common causes of bacterial endocarditis in adults today.

  • It is a type of valvular heart disease in which the valve between the left atrium and left ventricle does not close completely, resulting in a backward blood flow.

  • Mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation.

  • It results in the following:

    • Arrhythmia

    • Heart murmur

    • Dyspnea

    • Palpitations

    • edema

questions.text: The venous drainage of the Tela choroidea is through the internal cerebral vein, which drains into the?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Great cerebral vein:

  • The internal cerebral vein drains into a great cerebral vein.
  • The great cerebral vein (vein of Galen) is a deep cerebral vein formed by the basal veins of Rosenthal, the internal cerebral and a few superior cerebellar veins.
  • It is located in the quadrigeminal cistern, posterior to the brainstem and the brain's third ventricle.
  • The union of the thalami striate vein and the choroid vein results in the formation of the cerebral veins. These two veins untie beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum to form the great cerebral vein. The great cerebral vein is also called the vein of Galen.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sylvian vein:

  • Sylvian vein is the superficial middle cerebral vein that drains numerous small tributaries from the opercular areas around the lateral sulcus. This vein courses along the Sylvian fissure posteroanterior. Sylvian fissure is also known as insular cisterna, between the cerebrum temporal and frontal lobes.
  • A superficial middle cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus.

Option C - Straight sinus:

  • The straight sinus drains into the confluence of the sinus. The confluence of sinuses drains into the transverse sinus. The transverse sinus drains into the sigmoid sinus. The sigmoid sinus drains into the internal jugular vein. 

Option D - A and C:

  • It is an incorrect option as the internal cerebral vein drains into a great cerebral vein, not the straight sinus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and constipation. Physical examination reveals dry skin, coarse hair, and a diffuse, non-tender enlargement of the thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations show increased TSH and decreased serum levels of T4 and T3. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid gland is shown below. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells
Excess production of thyroglobulin by thyroid follicular cells
Decreased iodine intake in the diet

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autoimmune destruction of thyroid follicular cells:

  • This patient's clinical presentation of fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin, and coarse hair is consistent with hypothyroidism. The laboratory findings of increased TSH levels, decreased T3 and T4 levels, and diffuse non-tender enlargement of the thyroid gland are suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. The fine-needle aspiration biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cells seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that causes primary hypothyroidism. Autoimmune destruction occurs due to the production of autoantibodies against thyroid antigens, resulting in chronic inflammation and progressive destruction of thyroid follicular cells. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in India.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Excess production of thyroglobulin by thyroid follicular cells: While thyroglobulin is a protein involved in thyroid hormone synthesis, excess production of thyroglobulin would lead to increased production of thyroid hormones rather than decreased production of thyroid hormones as given in question.

Option C - Activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis: This mechanism would lead to increased TSH production and subsequent thyroid hormone synthesis, resulting in hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

Option D - Decreased iodine intake in the diet: Although iodine deficiency can cause hypothyroidism, this patient's presentation and histology findings is more consistent with autoimmune thyroiditis rather than iodine deficiency.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the physician complaining of a lump in her right breast that she noticed 4 months ago. After a complete workup, the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma is established. Before starting treatment, the physician suggests HER-2/neu immunohistochemistry staining. Which of the following scores on this patient’s test results will most likely need further confirmatory testing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2+:

  • This patient, who has been diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma, should have additional testing for molecular markers.
  • Overexpression of the HER-2 gene product results in the proliferation of tumor cells which is measured by immunohistochemistry.
  • The results are reported on a scale of 0 to 3+.
  • If the test yields a score of 2+, it is considered equivocal, and further testing with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is done to confirm a positive or negative status.
  • HER-2-positive breast cancer can be treated with trastuzumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody targeted against the HER-2 receptor.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of worsening headaches, nausea, and vomiting for the past month.  In the past three days, they have noticed he has been "wobbly" when walking, losing his balance, and falling frequently. Examination shows a broad-based gait and difficulty with heel-to-toe walking. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals the following.. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Medulloblastoma:

  • This patient has a medulloblastoma. This is the most common malignant brain tumor of childhood and is exclusively located within the cerebellum. It accounts for 20% of primary tumors of the central nervous system among children under 19 years of age, and incidence peaks between the ages of 5 and 9 years.
  • Patients with medulloblastoma present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP ), such as morning headaches, nausea, vomiting, altered mental statuses, and cerebellar dysfunction, such as gait ataxia, truncal instability, and limb incoordination, depending on the tumor location.
  • Symptoms typically develop over weeks to months and begin with those associated with raised ICP before those due to growth and invasion of the tumor within the cerebellum. Diplopia and dizziness may also result from the involvement of the cerebellum, brainstem, or cranial nerves.
  • Histology shows small round undifferentiated round cells with Homer Wright rosettes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are the most common primary brain tumor in childhood. They are well-circumscribed cystic tumors, often arising within the cerebellar hemispheres. Due to their slow-growing nature, symptoms usually develop over the years. When cysts are present in medulloblastomas, they are typically small and multiple rather than large solitary cysts.

Option C - Brainstem glioma:

  • Brainstem gliomas arise in the midbrain, pons, or medulla and account for 10-20% of central nervous system tumors in children. Most patients have a relatively long history of minor symptoms, which may have been present for over a decade.

Option D - Atypical teratoid:

  • Atypical teratoid, also known as rhabdoid tumors, are rare, highly malignant tumors primarily occurring in children less than three years of age. Two-thirds occur within the cerebellum, symptoms are location-dependent, and the prognosis is poor.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines should not be given along with the Yellow fever vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cholera vaccine:

  • Never give the yellow fever vaccine and cholera vaccine together.
  • Recent studies have shown that individuals receiving both yellow fever and cholera vaccines either simultaneously or with an interval of 1-3 weeks had reduced antibody responses to both vaccines. Unless time constraints are present, it's recommended to administer cholera and yellow fever vaccines with at least a 3-week interval between them.
  • There has to be a gap of 3 weeks

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • Tetanus, Hepatitis B, and Varicella vaccines can be given along with the Yellow fever vaccine

questions.text: Which type of sphenoidal pneumatization corresponds to Pneumatization reaching the anterior wall of Sella turcica?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pre-sellar pneumatization:

The Types o f pneumatization are

Conchal

Minimal or absent pneumatization, small cavity in sphenoid, mostly bony.

Presellar

Pneumatization reaches anterior wall of Sella turcica (most common).

Sellar

Pneumatization extends to posterior wall of sella Turcica.

Post Sellar

Pneumatization goes beyond posterior wall of Sella Turcica

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sellar pneumatization: Sellar pneumatization refers to pneumatization extending to the posterior wall of Sella turcica.

Option C – Post-sellar pneumatization: Post-sellar pneumatization refers to pneumatization extending beyond the posterior wall of sella turcica.

Option D - Conchal pneumatization: Conchal pneumatization refers to minimal or absent pneumatization.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arthus reaction:

  • Deposition of circulating immune complexes occurs in type III hypersensitivity.
  • The antigen-antibody (mostly IgG) complexes activates complement, which attracts neutrophils; neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes.
  • It can be associated with vasculitis and systemic manifestations.
  • Arthus reaction is a local subacute immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Intradermal injection of antigen into a pre-sensitized (has circulating IgG) individual leads to the immune complex formation in the skin (e.g., enhanced local reaction to a booster vaccination).
  • Serum sickness is the prototypic immune complex disease. Antibodies to foreign proteins are produced and 1–2 weeks later, antibody-antigen complexes form and deposit in tissues, complement activation inflammation and tissue damage (serum C3, C4).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asthma:

  • Asthma is a classic example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • IgE are already produced and fixed to mast cells- mast cell degranulation causes the release of mediators.
  • This leads to the later recruitment of inflammatory cells.
  • Resulting in vascular dilation, oedema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, and inflammation.
  • Examples are anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma (atopic forms)

Option C - Contact dermatitis:

  • Contact dermatitis is an example of a cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Two mechanisms, each involving T cells:
    1. Direct cell cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T cells kill targeted cells.
    2. Inflammatory reaction: effector CD4+
  • T cells recognize antigens and release inflammation-inducing cytokines.
  • The response does not involve antibodies (vs types I, II, and III).
  • Examples are contact dermatitis (e.g., poison ivy, nickel allergy) & graft-versus-host disease.
  • This principle is used in clinical tests such as purified protein derivatives for tuberculosis infection, patch tests for contact dermatitis & candida skin test for T cell immune function.

Option D - Rheumatic fever:

  • Rheumatic fever is an example of type II hypersensitivity.
  • IgG hypersensitivity reaction is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Antibodies to the M protein of group A streptococcus cross-react with self-antigens, and cross-react with myocardial antigen, due to molecular mimicry.
  • Antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens or extracellular matrix and causecellular destruction, inflammation, and cellular dysfunction.
  • Cellular destruction occurs when a cell is opsonized (coated) by antibodies, leading to either phagocytosis and/or activation of the complement system & natural cell killing (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples are autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (including drug-induced form), immune thrombocytopenia, transfusion reactions & hemolytic disease of the newborn.
  • Inflammation is mediated by the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces, activation of the complement system, and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation.
  • Examples are Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever & hyperacute transplant rejection.
  • Cellular dysfunction by antibodies binds to cell-surface receptors, abnormal blockade or activation of the downstream process.
  • Examples are myasthenia gravis, graves disease & pemphigus Vulgaris.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bile acid sequestrants (resins) is true in the context of pregnancy?

choices.text: Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy.
Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.
Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy.
Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.

Explanation:

  • In pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia is typically managed with lifestyle interventions (e.g., low-cholesterol diet, exercise) due to limited safety data on lipid-lowering drugs.
  • Statins, the standard for hypercholesterolemia, are contraindicated (FDA Category X) due to teratogenic risks (e.g., fetal skeletal abnormalities).
  • Bile acid sequestrants are considered relatively safe in pregnancy (FDA Category B for cholestyramine, Category C for colesevelam) because they are not systemically absorbed, minimizing fetal exposure.
  • They are used in severe cases, such as FH with high cardiovascular risk (e.g., LDL-C >190 mg/dL or vascular disease), when benefits outweigh risks. However, resins are the preferred pharmacologic option when therapy is unavoidable, as per AHA and ACOG guidance.
  • Close monitoring is required for maternal nutrient deficiencies (e.g., fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, K) and potential fetal risks (e.g., vitamin K deficiency affecting coagulation).

 

Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy (Option A): Resins are lipid-lowering agents used for hypercholesterolemia, not diabetes management, and have no role in controlling blood glucose or insulin requirements.

Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy (Option C): Resins are not used for CKD management, as they target hypercholesterolemia, not renal function or CKD-specific issues. While CKD patients may have dyslipidemia, lipid management in pregnancy follows the same principles as for hypercholesterolemia, with resins considered only for severe hyperlipidemia, not CKD itself.

Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy (Option D): Colesevelam, a bile acid sequestrant, is FDA-approved for hypercholesterolemia and glycemic control in type 2 diabetes (non-pregnant adults). No bile acid sequestrant, including colesevelam, has specific FDA approval for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with multiple hamartomas in the skin, breast, and mucous membranes. The most common feature of this condition is multiple trichilemmomas, and the affected gene is PTEN on chromosome 10. Ectodermal and endodermal polyps are observed. Which condition is most likely to be associated with the described clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cowden's Disease:

  • Cowden's disease, also known as multiple hamartoma syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis. The key features supporting this choice include:
  1. Multiple Hamartomas
  2. Trichilemmomas
  3. The affected gene in Cowden's disease is PTEN, located on chromosome 10.
  4. Ectodermal and Endodermal Polyps
  5. Increased Risk of Malignancies

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome:

  • Skin Pigmentary Changes: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is associated with skin pigmentary changes, hair loss, and onychodystrophy

Option B - Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome:

  • Hamartomatous Polyps: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract.

Option D - Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT):

  • Vascular Abnormalities: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia primarily involves vascular abnormalities, including telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations.

questions.text: Which of the following activates the Alternative pathway of Complement system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgA:

  • The Alternative pathway of the complement system is activated by IgA

Incorrect Options:

Option A & D- Immune complex(Ag-Ab) lgM & IgG):

  • Immune complex(Ag-Ab) lgM and IgG activate the Classical pathway of the Complement system

Option B - Microbial organisms:

  • Microbial organism activate the MBL pathway of the complement system

questions.text: A primigravida with a twin pregnancy at 38 weeks the pregnancy is admitted in labor. The obstetrician advises the patient to get a quick ultrasound to check for the presentation of both twins. The most common presentation is
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Vertex-vertex

  • This is the most common presentation in twins, where both fetuses are positioned head-down in the uterus. It is considered an optimal presentation for a vaginal delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Vertex-breech

  • This is the 2nd most common presentation
  • In this presentation, one twin is positioned head-down (vertex), and the other is positioned buttocks or feet first (breech).

Option C: Breech-breech

  • In the Breech-Breech presentation, both twins are positioned buttocks or feet first. This presentation is associated with increased complexities and risks during delivery.

Option D: Vertex-brow

  •  The Vertex-brow presentation involves one twin positioned head-down with the brow (forehead) presenting first. This is a less common presentation and may pose challenges during delivery. It is associated with a higher risk of complications.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the ER with palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. He is on long-term theophylline therapy. His heart rate is 120 beats per minute, blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. An electrocardiogram is performed, which is shown below:



Which of the following statements are true about the treatment of this condition?

choices.text: DC shock is the preferred treatment of choice
Amiodarone cannot be given as a long term treatment modality
Verapamil acts on SA node and stabilizes the heart rate
Metoprolol when given causes stabilization of the membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Amiodarone cannot be given as a long-term treatment modality:

  • The combination of an irregular rhythm with varying P-wave morphologies in a patient on theophylline therapy for COPD is consistent with the diagnosis of Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT).
  • Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic medication with a membrane-stabilizing effect, can be recommended for the treatment of MAT. However, its potential for toxicity limits its use as a long-term treatment option.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A-DC shock is the preferred treatment of choice: DC shock is not the preferred treatment for Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT) because it is ineffective in the presence of theophylline toxicity and does not provide long-term benefit.

Option C- Verapamil acts on SA node and stabilizes the heart rate: Verapamil primarily acts on the AV node, not the SA node, and is not the preferred medication for managing MAT.

Option D- Metoprolol when given causes stabilization of the membrane: Metoprolol works by blocking adrenaline's effects on the heart, but it does not directly stabilize the membrane. It is used to manage heart rate and symptoms in MAT.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most useful in differentiating between paralytic and restrictive squint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Forced duction test:

  • The forced duction test is the most useful test in differentiating between paralytic and restrictive squint. It helps determine the cause of the deviation by assessing the degree of motility of the affected eye. The forced duction test involves attempting to move the eye passively in various directions while the patient fixates on an object. In a paralytic squint, the eye can be moved easily, while in a restrictive squint, the eye cannot be moved easily due to mechanical restriction. This test helps differentiate between the two conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cover-uncover test: This test is commonly used to detect and measure heterophoria or manifest strabismus. The patient fixates on an object, one eye is covered and then uncovered. Any movement of the uncovered eye indicates strabismus. While it helps assess the presence and magnitude of squint, it doesn't specifically differentiate between paralytic and restrictive squint.

Option C - Prism cover test: The prism cover test is used to measure the magnitude and type of squint. It involves covering one eye with a prism while the other eye fixates on a target. The prism is gradually increased until the eyes are aligned. While it provides information about the deviation, it does not specifically differentiate between paralytic and restrictive squint.

Option D – Electroretinography: Electroretinography is a test that measures the electrical response of the retina to light stimulation. It is not directly related to assessing squint or differentiating between paralytic and restrictive squint. This test is more commonly used in the evaluation of retinal function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complains of difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds, such as birds chirping or the ringing of a phone. Which part of the auditory pathway is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Superior olivary complex

  • The superior olivary complex is an important structure in the auditory pathway involved in sound localization and processing of auditory signals.
  • It receives information from both ears and helps in comparing and integrating sound inputs to determine the location of the sound source.
  • Difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds can be attributed to a problem in the superior olivary complex since it plays a role in analyzing different frequency components of sound.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cochlear Nucleus:

  • The cochlear nucleus is one of the early stages in the auditory pathway where the signals from the cochlea are first processed. It is responsible for receiving and processing auditory information from the cochlea.
  • However, difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds is unlikely to be directly related to a problem in the cochlear nucleus.

Option C - Inferior colliculus:

  • The inferior colliculus is another important structure in the auditory pathway located in the midbrain.
  • It receives auditory information from the superior olivary complex and is involved in further processing and routing of sound signals to higher auditory centers.
  • While the inferior colliculus is important for sound processing, it is less likely to be the primary site of difficulty in understanding high-frequency sounds.

Option D - Medial geniculate body:

  • The medial geniculate body is part of the thalamus and serves as a relay station for auditory information between the inferior colliculus and the auditory cortex. It helps in processing and transmitting auditory signals to the auditory cortex for further analysis and perception.
  • Difficulty understanding high-frequency sounds is less likely to be directly associated with a problem in the medial geniculate body.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			
			
			
			A
			
			
			Weber’s test
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			
			
			
			B

questions.text:
Which of the following structures form the floor of the triangle marked below?



Which of the following structures form the floor of the triangle marked above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Internal Oblique:

  • The triangle marked above is the Lumbar triangle of Petit. It is a triangular space present in the posterolateral part of the lumbar region.
  • The boundaries of the triangle of Petit are:
    • Inferiorly: iliac crest
    • Superiorly: the apex of the triangle
    • Anteriorly: external oblique muscle
    • Posteriorly: latissimus dorsi muscle
  • The floor of the Petit triangle is formed by the internal oblique muscle, which is marked in the diagram shown in the question.
  • Following are the potential sites of hernia in the lateral abdominal wall:

Types of Lateral abdominal wall hernias

Location

Inferior lumbar hernia

Triangle of Petit

Superior lumbar hernia

Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfeltt-Lesshaft triangle). It is bounded by the 12th rib, erector spinae, and internal oblique muscles.

Lumbar incisional hernia

Following surgery involving the posterolateral abdominal wall

Spigelian hernia

Along the semilunar line
  • The following diagram labels the structures shown in the diagram in the question:

  • The triangle of Petit is an area of potential weakness; therefore, it can be a site of hernias. The hernias that occur through this triangle are known as lumbar hernias or Petit’s hernias.

Option A: Erector spinae

  • The erector spinae is a group of muscles that extends from the sacrum to the skull on the sides of the spinous processes of the vertebra. They do not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of the Petit.

Option C: Rectus abdominis

  • The rectus abdominis is in the front midline of the body wall, extending from the pubic symphysis to the xiphoid process and rib cage. It does not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of Petit.

Option D: Fascia transversalis

  • The fascia transversalis forms the posterior lamina of the rectus sheath. It does not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of Petit.

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 50 kg who exhales 200 ml/min of CO2 and consumed 250 ml/min O2.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 0.8:

  • To calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ), we need to determine the ratio of carbon dioxide production (VCO2) to oxygen consumption (VO2). The formula for RQ is:
    • RQ = VCO2 / VO2
    • Given the values: CO2 exhaled (VCO2) = 200 ml/min O2 consumed (VO2) = 250 ml/min
    • Substituting these values into the formula:
      • RQ = 200 ml/min / 250 ml/min RQ = 0.8

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 39-year-old HIV-positive male patient presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. His latest CD4 count is measured to be 420/mm3. He is currently asymptomatic. At what CD4 count should prophylaxis against Pneumocystis carinii infection be initiated according to current guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Start when the CD4 < 350/mm3:

  • Prophylaxis of opportunistic infection: Pneumocystis carinii (also known as pneumocystis jiroveci)
  • One double strength tablet = 800mg sulfamethoxazole + 160 mg trimethoprim
  • Start when the CD4 < 350/mm3
  • Stop when the CD4 >350/mm3 on two occasions six months apart + ascending trend of CD4 + no WHO stage 3 and 4

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: At what age, the child can follow rapidly moving objects?
questions.solution:

Incorrect Options:

  • Can follow the red dangling ring to 180 degrees

Option B - 4 months:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male chronic smoker came with dysphagia and weight loss symptoms. Dysphagia was initially for solids, but it progressed to liquids, too. He now complains of heartburn, chest pain, and repeated attacks of pneumonia. The barium swallow findings are given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding his diagnosis?

choices.text: Overall most common site is the lower third
The chemotherapy regimen given is Cisplatin + epirubicin
Endoscopic Ultrasound is the investigation of choice for the staging of carcinoma esophagus
The most common type of CA Esophagus worldwide is Adenocarcinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Endoscopic Ultrasound is the investigation of choice for the staging of carcinoma esophagus:

  • EUS is the most accurate modality for locoregional staging of esophageal cancer. It is a minimally invasive procedure that uses high-frequency sound waves to visualize the layers of the esophageal wall and surrounding tissues, thereby evaluating the primary tumor and locoregional adenopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Overall most common site is the lower third:

  • The middle third of the Esophagus is the most common site for squamous cell carcinoma.

Option B - Chemotherapy regimen given is Cisplatin + epirubicin:

  • Common chemotherapy drugs for esophageal cancer are fluorouracil, capecitabine, cisplatin, epirubicin, and docetaxel.

Option D - The most common type of CA Esophagus worldwide is Adenocarcinoma:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma is the most prevalent esophageal cancer worldwide.

questions.text: A 32-year-old individual presents with fever,  fatigue, jaundice and hepatomegaly. The patient recently travelled to a region known for sandfly infestations. There is no evidence of rash or lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests reveal hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely causative agent responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bartonella bacilliformis:

  • The patient's symptoms of fever, fatigue, hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and recent travel to a region with sandfly infestations are suggestive of Bartonella bacilliformis infection, also known as Oroya fever or Carrion's disease.
  • B. bacilliformis is transmitted by the bite of the female sand fly of the genus Lutzomyia spp.
  • Acute febrile illness during the first phase (Oroya fever) followed by a chronic phase (verruga peruana) with hemangioma-like skin lesions. In this case, the patient is likely in the acute phase, experiencing fever and hemolytic anemia. The lack of rash or lymphadenopathy is consistent with the early phase of the disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Plasmodium falciparum: It is the causative agent of malaria transmitted by female anopheles.

Option B - Trypanosoma cruzi: It is the causative agent of Chagas disease transmitted by reduviid bugs.

Option C - Leishmania donovani: It is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis transmitted by female sandfly, characterized by fever, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly, but it does not typically lead to hemolytic anaemia and jaundice.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements and choose the appropriate answer.

choices.text: Statements 1 and 2 are true and 2 is an adequate explanation to 1.

Incorrect Options:
