questions.text: What is the advanced molecular mechanism of action of the following substance?

choices.text: Modulates contrast in tumors situated within the blood-brain barrier (BBB)

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Alters T1 relaxation: Magnevist (gadolinium-based contrast agent) primarily acts by increasing T1 relaxation during magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). When gadolinium is administered, it shortens the T1 relaxation time of nearby protons, leading to enhanced signal intensity in T1-weighted images. This increased contrast helps in visualizing structures like blood vessels and enhancing the visibility of certain pathological conditions in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Induces signal decay:

  • Gadolinium-based contrast agents, like Magnevist, primarily affect T1 relaxation rather than inducing signal decay. They are known to increase signal intensity in T1-weighted images.

Option B- Reverse-phase contrast:

  • Magnevist is not a reverse-phase contrast. It primarily induces positive contrast.

Option D- Modulates contrast in tumors situated within the blood-brain barrier (BBB):

  • While gadolinium contrast is used to enhance the visualization of tumors, it is limited to only those which lie outside the blood-brain barrier (BBB).

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 14 weeks of gestation came to the clinic for an antenatal checkup. On examination and evaluation by Transabdominal sonography, the fetus is found to be dead. Further evaluation reveals the presence of thrombi in the blood vessels. Which of the following is not an inherited cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anticardiolipin antibodies:

  • Anticardiolipin antibodies are an acquired cause of thrombophilia that causes abortion
  • The condition due to which the baby dies in the scenario is Thrombophilia
  • It is characterized by an affinity to make thrombus
  • Small blood vessels are present in the placenta supplying nutrition to the baby
  • If thrombi are made in these blood vessels, they get blocked, and the baby dies
  • Other acquired causes include Lupus Anticoagulant and Anti Beta(symbol)2 Glycoprotein Antibodies

Incorrect Options

Options A, B, C:

  • These are the inherited causes of Thrombophilia

questions.text: Which atypical antipsychotic is associated with the highest risk of causing elevated prolactin levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Risperidone:

  • Risperidone, among the atypical antipsychotics listed, is associated with the highest risk of causing elevated prolactin levels, which can lead to adverse effects such as galactorrhea and amenorrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Pimavanserin:

  • Pimavanserin has the least risk of causing elevated prolactin levels among the listed atypical antipsychotics.

Option B- Clozapine:

  • Clozapine is associated with a lower risk of causing elevated prolactin levels compared to risperidone.

Option D- Haloperidol:

  • Haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic, is associated with the maximum risk of causing elevated prolactin levels. Among the options provided, it poses the highest risk, but among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone has a higher risk than haloperidol.

questions.text: A biopsy of a lung mass is done, and the histopathological finding is shown below. On immunohistochemical studies of this biopsy specimen, which of the following tumor markers would likely show strong expression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:

  •  The biopsy shows well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with prominent keratinization with keratin pearl formation, the most likely type of lung cancer is squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC), which tends to occur centrally and can cause bronchial obstruction.
  • The tumor marker most likely to show strong expression in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is cytokeratin.
  • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha-fetoprotein:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and yolk sac carcinoma.

Option B - Calretinin:

  • Calretinin is a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C - Carcinoembryonic antigen:

  • Carcinoembryonic antigen is a marker for colonic carcinoma and many other malignancies (pancreatic Ca, lung Ca).

questions.text: A 30-years-old primigravida with diabetes mellitus at 30 weeks gestation is admitted to the ICU with multiorgan dysfunction. She is oriented in time and place. She has had mild lower abdominal pain for the last few days and reports no trauma history. Her lab parameters suggest thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and an INR of 2.1. Her blood sugar level is 180mg/dL. Which of the following is a common underlying cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Abruptio placenta

  • Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics due to the associated bleeding and activation of the clotting system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gestational diabetes

  • Gestational diabetes is diagnosed in pregnant patients after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Such patients have underlying risk factors, such as obesity and prior gestational diabetes.
  • Patients who have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus before pregnancy cannot be diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
  • DIC is not caused by GDM, however, chances of DIC are higher in overt diabetics

Option C: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is the attachment of the placenta at or near the internal cervical opening instead of its normal attachment site.
  • It causes visible external bleeding.
  • Placenta previa does not cause DIC unless associated with massive hemorrhage​​​

Option D: Rupture of the uterus

  • The uterus rupture is an obstetrics emergency that leads to the rapid demise of the fetus and/or mother.
  • Emergency C-section with the repair of the uterus is indicated.
  • Uterine rupture would cause DIC only if associated with massive hemorrhage

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of scalp itching. He reports that many of his classmates are experiencing similar symptoms. On examination, gray scaly lesions are observed on the scalp, along with broken hair. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Tinea capitis:

  • The clinical presentation of gray scaly lesions on the scalp and broken hair is most consistent with tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp. Tinea capitis commonly causes itching and can be transmitted among individuals, such as classmates in this case. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pediculosis capitis: Pediculosis capitis or lice infection, would typically show the presence of lice and nits (eggs) attached to the hair shafts. While lice infestation can cause itching, the gray scaly lesions and broken hair seen in this case are more indicative of tinea capitis.

Option C – Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-defined, red, scaly plaques on the scalp, often accompanied by silvery scales. The gray scaly lesions and broken hair observed in this scenario are not consistent with the characteristic presentation of psoriasis.

Option D - Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that can affect the scalp, causing red, itchy, flat-topped papules or plaques. However, the gray scaly lesions and broken hair described in the clinical scenario are not typical findings of lichen planus.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and hepatomegaly. A diagnostic workup is initiated, including an abdominal ultrasound. An ultrasound is performed:



Mark the incorrect statement regarding the condition:

choices.text: It is the most common cause of liver transplant in children
It’s management includes the Kasai procedure
It shows a triangular cord sign

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Enlarged gallbladder is seen

  • The triangular cord sign is observed in the image, indicating an echogenic area adjacent to the portal vein.
  • This finding suggests fibrosis, and when combined with the clinical presentation of the infant, it raises suspicion of biliary atresia.
  • In biliary atresia, the gallbladder is typically atretic and not dilated.

Biliary Atresia: 

  1. Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
  2. Risk Factors: There is no specific known cause, but certain genetic and prenatal factors may contribute.
  3. Clinical Symptoms: Infants may present with jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.
  4. Investigations:
    • Triangular cord sign on imaging (ultrasound).
    • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) can help evaluate biliary flow.
    • Liver biopsy may reveal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation.
  5. Management: Early intervention is crucial. The Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) is performed to restore bile flow. If this is unsuccessful, liver transplantation may be considered.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is the most common cause of liver transplant in children:

  • Biliary atresia is the most common indication of liver transplant

Option B - It’s management includes the Kasai procedure:

  • Surgical management involves the Kasai procedure. It has a good outcome if done <8 weeks of age.

Option D - It shows a triangular cord sign:

  • The ultrasound given in the image shows a triangular cord sign. It is a feature of biliary atresia.

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset weakness of both lower limbs. On examination, she has flaccid paralysis without any sensory deficits. Considering the clinical presentation, which of the following age groups is associated with acute flaccid paralysis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - 0-15 years

  • Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) is characterized by the sudden onset of weakness or loss of muscle tone and reflexes in one or more limbs.
  • It can be caused by various infectious agents, including poliovirus, enteroviruses, and other pathogens.
  • In the context of the scenario described, where a girl presents with sudden onset weakness of both lower limbs, acute flaccid paralysis should be considered.
  • This condition is seen in children under the age of 15, with the highest incidence typically occurring in children under 5 years old.

 

Incorrect options: B,C,D

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe, crushing chest pain radiating to the left jaw that started 2 hours ago. ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V2-V6. He undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention and is started on antiplatelet and antithrombotic medications. Three weeks later, he returned with chest pain and a friction rub on auscultation. What is the pathogenesis of the problem that has arisen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Autoimmunity:

  • The constellation of symptoms in this patient is consistent with Dressler syndrome (post-MI pericarditis)
  • Dressler syndrome is a delayed autoimmune-mediated inflammatory response that occurs several weeks after an acute myocardial infarction (MI). It is characterized by inflammation of the pericardium, which can lead to chest pain and a friction rub heard on auscultation.
  • The immune system mistakenly targets healthy cardiac tissue, causing inflammation and the characteristic symptoms associated with Dressler syndrome.

Post-MI Complication

Time Frame

Arrhythmias

Hours to days

Heart Failure

Hours to days

Cardiogenic Shock

Hours

Ventricular Septal Rupture

Days

Papillary Muscle Rupture

Days

Free Wall Rupture

Days

Dressler Syndrome

Weeks

Thromboembolism

Days to weeks

Ventricular Aneurysm

Days to weeks

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infection: While infections can lead to inflammation of the pericardium (pericarditis), the timing and clinical presentation described in the case scenario are more indicative of Dressler syndrome

Option C - Infarction: The patient's initial presentation was of infarction event. However, the problem that has arisen during the follow-up visit, characterized by chest pain and a friction rub, is not due to a new infarction. It is more consistent with Dressler syndrome

Option D - Adverse Drug Reaction: While adverse drug reactions are always possible, there is no evidence or indication in the case scenario to suggest that the patient's current symptoms of chest pain and a friction rub are due to an adverse drug reaction. The patient's symptoms are more in line with Dressler syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, who is a known case of AIDScame to the hospital with complaints of frequent episodes of fever, cough, and breathing difficulty. His history revealed that he is on anti-retroviral therapy. A bronchoalveolar lavage was examined with GMS stain and is shown below. The chest x-ray showed perihilar infiltrates and HRCT was done, which is shown below. LDH is elevated with deranged SpO2 and a CD4 count <200 cells/mm^3 of blood.What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IV Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole:

  • The patient has HIV infection with a CD4 count <200 cells/mm^3
  • Perihilar infiltrates on chest x-ray,d ground glass opacities on HRCT, and the BAL sample stained with Gomori methenamine stain showing multiple black color cysts proves the presence of Pneumocystis Jiroveci.
  • Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for this infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, D: 

  • These are used as a part of treatment regime but not the drug of choice

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with early morning nausea and vomiting for 1 month. He also complains of blurred vision and headache, which worsens while defecating and straining. Fundoscopy reveals severe bilateral papilledema. A raised intracranial pressure is suspected. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved first in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abducens nerve:

  • Abducens is the sixth cranial nerve which is a pure motor nerve and supplies lateral rectus. After leaving the pontomedullary junction, it enters the subarachnoid space and after a variable distance, it penetrates the dura and leaves the intramural space.
  • It travels through the osteofibrous Dorello's canal under the petrosphenoidal ligament (PSL), also known as Gruber's ligament. It then penetrates the cavernous sinus, riding along with the inferior petrosal sinus. In the cavernous sinus, it lies immediately lateral to the pericarotid sympathetics.
  • Abducens nerve has the longest subarachnoid course. Therefore, whenever there is suspicion of raised intracranial pressure, the abducens nerve is affected first.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve has the longest intracranial route. It is very thin in diameter and it is the only nerve that has a dorsal origin. However, it is not the most common nerve affected by raised intracranial pressure.

Option C - Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal is the thickest nerve in diameter. It is a mixed nerve, and it is least likely to be affected by the raised intracranial pressure

Option D - Facial nerve: The facial nerve has the longest intraosseous route. It is mostly affected by ear infections, e.g. Herpes zoster oticus or Ramsay Hunt syndrome. It is not a commonly affected nerve following a raised intracranial pressure

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic by his father complaining of fever along with a rash that began on the first day of fever. On examination, the rash is pleomorphic. The doctor explained to the interns that it is caused by a DNA virus from the Herpesviridae family and the incubation period is 10-12 days. Which among the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Otitis media:

  • The condition that is described in the question is Chickenpox
  • It is caused by Varicella zoster virus
  • Otitis media is not a complication of this disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stroke

Option B - Transverse myelitis

Option C - Optic neuritis

  • These are the complications of Chickenpox

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivered a baby boy weighing 2.2 kg. On examination, the baby appeared to be stable and active. The pediatrician advised skin-to-skin contact of the neonate with the mother as an efficacious alternative to warmer care. What is the recommended duration for this care process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Minimum 1 hour per session: 

  • Kangaroo mother care refers to the care of preterm or low birth weight infants by placing the infant in skin-to-skin contact with the mother or any other caregiver.
  • Initially perceived as an alternative to warmer care for LBW infants, KMC has now become the standard of care for these babies.
  • Is as good as incubator care regarding safety and thermal protection.
  • A minimum of 1 hour per session of KMC should be done.
  • Sessions that last less than an hour should be avoided because frequent handling may stress the baby.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Minimum 2 hours per session / Minimum 3 hours per session & Minimum 4 hours per session: These are not correct.

questions.text: What is the pattern of inheritance in patients with cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autosomal recessive:

  • Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting exocrine gland function, most prevalent in Northern European individuals at a rate of 1 in 3500.
  • It is a chronic disease that often leads to chronic sino-pulmonary infections and pancreatic insufficiency. The most common cause of death is end-stage pulmonary disease.
  • It is caused by a mutation in a gene on chromosome 7 that encodes a protein transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein. This protein functions as a transmembrane cAMP-activated chloride channel.
  • Being autosomal recessive, both gene copies are mutated in clinical disease.
  • Autosomal recessive conditions result from mutations in genes on the autosomal chromosomes.
  • Disease outcomes for a child with carrier patients in autosomal recessive disease include:
    • ​​​25% chance that the child is born with two normal genes and will neither be a carrier nor express the disease.
    • 50% chance that the child is born with one abnormal and one normal gene, i.e., would be a carrier without the disease.
    • 25% chance that the child is born with two abnormal genes, i.e., at risk for the disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - X-linked recessive:

  • Cystic fibrosis is not an x-linked recessive disorder.
  • X-linked recessive conditions result from mutations in genes on the X chromosome.
  • Males are much more frequently affected as compared to females.
  • Examples include Hemophilia A.

Option C - Autosomal dominant:

  • In an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, mutated genes are located on non-sex chromosomes, and a single copy of the mutated gene is enough to express the disease.
  • Affected parents have a 50% chance of transferring mutated genes to their children.
  • In autosomal dominant inheritance, males and females are both affected.
  • Examples include Achondroplasia and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Option D - X-linked dominant:

  • X-linked dominant inheritance is a mode of inheritance in which an X chromosome carries the dominant gene. This means that the gene causing the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and only one copy of the allele is sufficient to express the disease if inherited from a diseased parent.
  • The affected father, carrying the x-linked dominant disorder, will pass on the disease to all the daughters but not to any son.
  • If the mother is affected, then sons will have a chance of being affected depending on whether a recessive or dominant X chromosome is passed on.

questions.text: What condition is related to a 3-year-old with diarrhea, runny nose, fever, erythematous rash on the face, and upper limb pain, whose mother had a history of blood transfusion during pregnancy?

choices.text: Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection:

  • People who do not have P antigen, which is the cellular receptor for parvovirus B19, are naturally resistant to infection with this pathogen.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses. 
  • They belong to the family Parvoviridae.
  • Shows tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. → aplastic crises in Sickle cell anaemic patients
  • Tropism for RBCs: It infects RBC precursors by using P blood group Ag as a receptor.
  • Transmission: Most commonly by the respiratory route, followed by blood transfusion and transplacental transmission (occurs in 30% of cases with maximum risk in the second trimester).
  • Associated with:
    • NIHF (non-immune hydrops fetalis).
    • Polyarthralgia syndrome- Pain is more in upper limb joints than lower limb joints.
    • Erythema infectiosum /5th disease- slapped check appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - <10% spread by transplacental route:

  • The most common mode of transmission is the respiratory route.
  • The transplacental transmission occurs in 30% or higher cases with maximum risk in the second trimester.

Option B - Parvovirus B19 exclusively infects animals:

  • Parvovirus only infects humans.

Option C - It is an RNA virus:

  • It is not a RNA virus.
  • Parvovirus is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text:
In the graph below, Curve A is obtained for liver glucokinase, while Curve B is for muscle glucokinase under similar conditions.

 



Which is the correct statement regarding the relationship between these enzymes?

choices.text: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor
B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.
At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.
B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A:

  • B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.
  • Km is determined from substrate concentration at half of enzyme's Vmax.

  • The graph indicates B's higher Km as it has higher Vmax compared to A.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor:

  • A is the same enzyme as B but with a competitive inhibitor. If so, both would have equal Vmax, contrary to the graph.

Option B - B has a greater affinity for glucose than A:

  • B has greater glucose affinity than A. Affinity relates to lower Km; hence, A's lower Km implies higher affinity for glucose.

Option C - At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics:

  • Both enzymes display first-order kinetics at maximal substrate concentrations. Yet, at this point, enzyme binding sites are saturated, suggesting zero-order kinetics, not first-order.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (MTLE) are true except:

choices.text: Small hippocampus with increased signal on T2-weighted sequences is observed
There is no significant history of seizure in the past
Seizures originate from the hippocampus and typically propagate to the basal temporal regions
Hippocampal sclerosis is observed with pyramidal cell loss in the CA1, CA3, and CA4 regions. This loss of cells is associated with tissue stiffening, also known as "Ammon's horn sclerosis."

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - There is no significant history of seizure in the past:

  • Having a history of febrile seizures in childhood can be an important sign of developing MTLE. A study conducted on children with febrile status epilepticus (FEBSTAT) showed that about 10% of the children had acute hippocampal injury.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are true regarding MTLE.

  • The 3 statements are associated with hippocampal sclerosis, which is the main pathology associated with MTLE.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cryptococcus:

  • Cryptococcus is a genus of fungi that includes pathogenic species, most notably Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii. These fungi are encapsulated yeast-like organisms and can cause serious infections, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.
  • India ink staining is a diagnostic technique used to visualize Cryptococcus species in clinical samples, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The ink particles do not penetrate the capsule surrounding the Cryptococcus cells, resulting in a clear halo around the unstained organisms against the dark background. This "halo effect" is a characteristic feature observed in India ink preparations for Cryptococcus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspergillus: These are filamentous fungi characterized by their acute dichotomous branching, septate hyphae, and conidial structures. Specific staining techniques such as lactophenol cotton blue or potassium hydroxide (KOH) mounts are commonly employed to examine their hyphal structures and conidia.

Option B - Penicillium: These are dimorphic fungi characterized by brush/broom conidial structures. Specific staining techniques such as lactophenol cotton blue or potassium hydroxide (KOH) mounts are commonly employed to examine their hyphal structures and conidia.

Option D - Candida: Candida is a yeast-like fungus that forms budding cells rather than hyphae. Instead, techniques such as Gram staining, wet mounts with KOH, or specialized fungal stains like methylene blue or calcofluor white are commonly used to visualize Candida cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD in an anxious state, reporting early pregnancy loss 1 day back. She reports spontaneous abortion in the 5th week of her pregnancy. She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Uterus didelphys

  • Uterus didelphys is a complete failure of fusion of Mullerian duct resulting in two uteri, cervix, and vagina.
  • It can lead to pregnancy complications and dysmenorrhea. Few patients may have surgery to treat uterus didelphys, but most cases don't require it.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Bicornuate uterus

  • It is described as a heart-shaped uterus, having two sides instead of one hollow cavity.
  • The cervix and vagina are single

Option C: Subseptate uterus

  • It is a mild form of congenital anomaly in which a half septum is present within the uterus, not infringing on the cervix.

Option D: Unicornuate Uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder that causes a female to have only half a uterus.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with colicky pain in the lower abdomen. He also complains of absolute constipation. After performing a physical examination, an X-ray is ordered. The abdominal X-ray findings are given below:



Which of the following is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colonoscopic detorsion:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Barium enema: It is an incorrect option.

Option B - Elective sigmoid colectomy:

  • Elective sigmoid colectomy is done only after the colonoscopy detorsion

Option C - Air enema:

  • Air enema is helpful in intussusception cases but not in the case of volvulus

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of nasal obstruction and a unilateral nasal mass. On examination, a crescent sign is observed. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Excisional biopsy of the nasal mass

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery 

  • The surgery of choice for AC polyps is Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS).
  • FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for the removal of diseased tissues while preserving as much normal mucosa as possible. It is performed using an endoscope and helps to alleviate the symptoms caused by the polyp.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medical therapy with antibiotics:

  • According to the given information, medical therapy has no role in the treatment of Antrochoanal (AC) polyps. While antibiotics may be given to clear any associated infection, they will not resolve the polyp itself.

Option B - Observation and follow-up:

  • AC polyps typically require surgical intervention for definitive treatment. Observation and follow-up alone would not address the underlying problem.

Option D - Excisional biopsy of the nasal mass:

  • While it is important to evaluate any nasal mass, an excisional biopsy is not the primary treatment for AC polyps. FESS is the preferred surgical approach for these polyps.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with developmental delay, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent infections. His parents report that he also has episodes of diarrhoea and vomiting. Physical examination shows coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and a large tongue. Laboratory investigations reveal low platelet count and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Lysosomal storage diseases refer to the class of inborn metabolic error diseases characterized by the accumulation of excessive organ substrates due to a lack of lysosome enzymes. These are rare genetic disorders with symptoms ranging from developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly to recurrent infections.
  • Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disease involving the build-up of certain fatty substances in the spleen and liver. This accumulation of fatty substances causes the organs to enlarge, adversely affecting their function. The symptoms of Gaucher disease include coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, enlarged spleen and liver, yellow spots in eyes, bruising, fatigue, a large tongue, etc. Further, tests showing a low platelet count and elevated liver enzymes indicate a diagnosis of Gaucher disease.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in the enzymes sphingomyelinase or acid sphingomyelinase. A person having Niemann-Pick disease exhibits neurological symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and foam cells in the bone marrow. 

Option, C. Tay-Sachs disease is caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme. This leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons, causing progressive neurological degeneration. The common symptoms of this disease are muscular weakness, difficulty in speaking and swallowing, seizures, and hearing and vision loss.

Option D. Pompe disease is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes of various organs, including the heart, skeletal muscles, and liver causing weakness, cardiomyopathy, and respiratory failure. The symptoms of this disease include muscle weakness, feeding problem, enlarged heart, trouble in breathing and poor weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is commonly associated with automatism when used in conjunction with barbiturates and benzodiazepines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alcohol:

  • Automatism, which refers to automatic or involuntary behaviors, is commonly associated with alcohol use when combined with barbiturates and benzodiazepines. Alcohol potentiates the sedative effects of these drugs, leading to increased central nervous system depression and impairments in cognitive and motor functions. This combination can result in behaviors such as sleepwalking, confusion, and loss of inhibitions, contributing to the occurrence of automatism.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Nicotine:

  • Psychoactive substance found in tobacco.
  • Not typically associated with automatism when used with barbiturates and benzodiazepines.

Option B - Caffeine:

  • Stimulant found in coffee and tea.
  • Counteracts sedative effects of barbiturates and benzodiazepines.
  • Not associated with automatism when used with these drugs.

Option D - Cannabis:

  • Psychoactive substance, can have sedative effects.
  • Not commonly associated with automatism when used with barbiturates and benzodiazepines.

questions.text: Panitunumab is used in the treatment of all of the following cancers except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - HER negative breast cancer:

  • Panitunumab is used in the treatment of HER negative breast cancer
  • Sacituzumab has been approved for the treatment of HER-negative breast cancer

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A , B, and C are all the cancers for which Panitumumab has been approved.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the hospital by ambulance immediately after a car accident. The patient receives three emergency blood transfusions due to active bleeding and persistent hypotension. After 4 hours, the patient developed sudden respiratory distress. SpO2 is reduced to 80%, and PCWP is 16 mm Hg. Which of the following can be the reason behind this symptom in this patient that can lead to death?
questions.solution:
Option C: TRALI

  • The typical presentation of Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia ( O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.
  • TRALI results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release inflammatory mediators that increase capillary permeability.

              Cytokine released due to antigenic difference

                                     ↓

              Damage to the microvasculature of the lungs

                                     ↓

                                   TRALI

                                     ↓

                                    Death

  • The most common complication of blood transfusion leading to death is TRALI.

Option A: Hypokalemia

  • Massive blood transfusion usually causes hyperkalemia but rarely leads a patient to death.

Option B: Citrate toxicity

  • Citrate intoxication → Hypocalcemia, manifested by circumoral numbness and tingling sensation of the fingers and toes.
  • It is a complication of a massive blood transfusion, but it usually doesn't lead to death.

Option D: Hypothermia

  • Hypothermia is a complication that occurs due to a massive blood transfusion. But it doesn't lead to death.

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of direct local violence to conduct criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cupping:

  • CUPPING: A form of direct local violence, A mug is turned mouth downwards over a lighted wick and placed on the hypogastrium and the mug is pulled, which results in partial separation of the placenta. This is usually practiced in advanced pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B/ C - Abortion stick/ Electricity/ Syringing:

  • Higginson's syringing (AIR / Soap water in the uterus), rupturing the membrane (pointed object), abortion sticks, dilation of the cervix (slippery elm bark and drugs), Dilatation and Curettage, air insuﬄation.
  • All these are local methods used in criminal abortion.

questions.text: The muscle marked in green coloured is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Option D: Subcostal nerve

  • The muscle shown in the picture is pyramidalis.
  • It originates from the anterior surface of the pubis and is inserted in the linea alba.
  • The main action of pyramidal is to the tenses linea alba.
  • The 12th Thoracic nerve (subcostal nerve) supplies the following muscles
  1. Pyramidalis
  2. Rectus abdominis
  3. Intercostal muscles
  4. Anterior abdominal wall muscles.

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve

  • It originates from the anterior rami of the T12 and L1 nerve roots.
  • It supplies sensory innervations to the anterior surface of the scrotum in males or labia majora in females, the root of the penis or mons pubis, and some parts of the medial thigh.
  • It innervates the following muscles:
  1. Internal oblique
  2. Transversus abdominis muscles

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve

  • It originates from the lumbar plexus.
  • It gives sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions.
  • It supplies its motor innervation to the following muscles:
  1. ​​​​​​​Internal oblique muscles
  2. Transverse abdominal muscles.

Option C: Genitofemoral nerve

  • It provides sensory supply to the upper thigh region.
  • It supplies the mons pubis and labia majora in females and the skin of the anterior scrotum in males.
  • It supplies its motor innervation to the cremaster muscle.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of worsening vision, redness, pain, light sensitivity, and discharge from his right eye. He reports undergoing a cataract operation in the same eye 7 months ago. Upon examination, the patient demonstrates the ability to perceive hand movements, along with lid swelling, chemosis, corneal edema, and hypopyon. Vitritis is observed along with the presence of inflammatory cells and exudates in the vitreous. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intravitreal antibiotic injections:

  • The clinical scenario described is suggestive of endophthalmitis, an acute postoperative complication of cataract surgery, which is a purulent inflammation of intraocular fluids usually due to infection. The hallmark feature of endophthalmitis is progressive vitritis, along with other signs and symptoms such as worsening vision, redness, pain, photophobia, blepharospasm, and discharge. On examination, findings such as lid swelling, chemosis, corneal edema, hypopyon, and vitritis further support the diagnosis.
  • The treatment of choice for endophthalmitis with the ability to perceive hand movements is intravitreal antibiotic injections, typically including ceftazidime and vancomycin. These antibiotics are effective in targeting the infection within the eye. Systemic antibiotics, such as quinolones, may be given for their higher ocular penetration. Pars plana vitrectomy is indicated when there is no hand movement vision.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pars plana vitrectomy: Pars plana vitrectomy is not the treatment of choice for endophthalmitis. It is indicated only when there is no hand movement vision, and the patient described in the scenario has worsening vision but still retains hand movement or better vision.

Option C - Systemic antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics, such as quinolones, may be given in cases of endophthalmitis to provide additional coverage. However, they are not the primary treatment of choice for this condition. Intravitreal antibiotic injections are preferred for targeted delivery and higher efficacy.

Option D - Cycloplegics and topical steroids: Cycloplegics and topical steroids are used in the management of associated uveitis, which can occur in conjunction with endophthalmitis. However, they are not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis itself.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not fall in the category of disease under vision 2020 globally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diabetic retinopathy:

  • Diabetic retinopathy

  • Cataract
  • Childhood blindness

  • Trachoma
  • Onchocercariasis

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect

questions.text: What medical device, depicted below, is most likely recommended for a 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension and myocardial ischemia who is admitted to the cardiology ward due to rhythm issues?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Automated External Defibrillator:

  • The above image is of Automated External Defibrillator.
  • Automated External Defibrillator:
    • It is an advanced, microprocessor-based portable device.
    • High specificity and sensitivity in differentiating shockable from non-shockable rhythms. 
    • Delivers an electric shock through the chest to the heart, potentially stopping arrhythmias.
    • Compared with monophasic shocks, biphasic shocks deliver energy in two directions with equivalent efficacy at lower energy levels and possibly with less myocardial injury.
    • When using AEDs, one electrode pad is placed beside the upper right sternal border, just below the clavicle, and the other pad is placed just lateral to the left nipple, with the top of the pad a few inches below the axilla.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulse oximeter:

  • It is used to monitor the oxygen saturation.

Option B - Sphygmomanometer:

  • It is used to measure blood pressure.

Option C - Manual external defibrillator:

  • The manual device for defibrillation does not automatically identify and treat the abnormal rhythm.
  • However, the success rates are comparable to the automatic defibrillator

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago, which was resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gilbert syndrome:

  • Gilbert Syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting bilirubin processing in the liver due to a mutation in the UGT1A1 gene, which encodes the enzyme UGT.
  • Reduced UGT activity leads to bilirubin accumulation, causing jaundice during stress or illness.
  • Diagnosis involves blood tests for bilirubin levels, distinguishing it from other syndromes.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Rare disorder impacting bilirubin secretion, resulting in conjugated bilirubin buildup and skin discoloration. Contrastingly, Gilbert's syndrome involves unconjugated bilirubin accumulation.

Option B - Criggler-Najar type 1 syndrome: Rare genetic disorder causing severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, leading to jaundice and complications. Differs from Gilbert's syndrome due to the severity and UDP-glucuronosyltransferase deficiency.

Option D - Rotor syndrome: Rare disorder causing conjugated bilirubin accumulation, akin to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but distinguished by absence of dark pigments in urine, unlike Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of redness, swelling, and pain in the right leg with fever, chills, and nausea. He reports seeing liquid oozing from the affected area on his right leg. His temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), his pulse is 106/min, and his blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg. Examination of the right lower leg shows a large area of erythema with poorly-demarcated borders and purulent drainage. The area is fluctuant, warm, and tender to the touch.  In addition to incision, drainage, and taking cultures from the wound, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intravenous vancomycin:

  • This patient is most likely suffering from purulent cellulitis, a rapidly spreading local infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue. Cellulitis is caused most commonly by Streptococcus pyogenes and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It commonly appears in areas with broken skin (e.g., due to trauma or another infection). The diagnosis is usually clinical.
  • Intravenous vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA, making it the empirical treatment of choice for patients with purulent cellulitis and systemic signs of infection (e.g., tachycardia, fever).
  • Since infection by MRSA is becoming increasingly common, an antibiotic that covers MRSA is also required for empirical therapy in patients with a history of recent hospitalization, recent antibiotic use, penetrating trauma, injection drug use, or evidence of MRSA infection or colonization elsewhere.
  • Once culture and sensitivity results are available, a more targeted approach to antibiotic therapy should be pursued.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral clindamycin:

  • Clindamycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA. While clindamycin is one of the recommended empiric antibiotics for non-purulent cellulitis in patients who do not require parenteral therapy, it is not recommended for purulent cellulitis. Oral clindamycin is inappropriate for this patient with systemic signs of infection (tachycardia, fever).

Option C - Surgical debridement:

  • For patients with cellulitis, surgical debridement is indicated in the case of recurrent infection and necrotizing fasciitis and if cellulitis continues to spread despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.
  • This patient has no evidence of necrotizing fasciitis, such as pain out of proportion to the area of erythema, skin necrosis, or crepitus.

Option D - Oral dicloxacillin:

  • Dicloxacillin is a type of anti-staphylococcal penicillin that is indicated for nonpurulent cellulitis. However, it is not indicated for empiric treatment of purulent cellulitis because it is ineffective against MRSA.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the community health center by his parents. On examination, the child presents with thinning of hair, skin changes, and a distended abdomen. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoalbuminemia. The child is subsequently diagnosed with Kwashiorkar. Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with Kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Ribs are prominent:

  • Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition caused by protein deficiency.
  • The most commonly affected age group is children 6 months to 3 years.
  • Prominent ribs are not typically associated with Kwashiorkor.
  • Instead, in severe cases of malnutrition such as marasmus, where there is significant muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat, ribs may become prominent due to the lack of tissue covering.

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

  • More severe

  • Children with protein deficiency only

  • Age: 6 months to 3 years

  • Presence of subcutaneous fat

  • Edema is present

  • Presence of enlarged fatty liver

  • Ribs are not prominent

  • Lethargic

  • Mild or no muscle wasting

  • Poor appetite

  • Requires adequate proteins

  • More hair changes

  • Flaky paint like skin

  • Moon appearance

  • More common

  • Children with both protein and calorie deficiency

  • Age: from infants to less than one year

  • No subcutaneous fat

  • Edema is absent

  • No fatty liver

  • Ribs are prominent

  • Alert and irritable

  • Severe muscle wasting

  • Voracious feeder

  • Requires adequate fats, proteins and carbohydrates

  • Less hair changes

  • Wrinkled, dry face

  • Wise old man appearance

Incorrect options:

Option A - Presence of subcutaneous fat:

  • In Kwashiorkor, there is often the presence of subcutaneous fat, giving the child a swollen appearance despite being malnourished.
  • This is due to the imbalance in protein and carbohydrate intake, leading to the accumulation of adipose tissue.

Option B - Edema is present:

  • Edema, particularly bilateral pitting edema, is a hallmark feature of Kwashiorkor.
  • It occurs due to decreased oncotic pressure resulting from hypoalbuminemia, leading to fluid retention in the interstitial spaces.

Option C - Presence of enlarged fatty liver:

  • In Kwashiorkor, there is often hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of fat in the liver, leading to fatty liver.
  • This occurs as a consequence of altered lipid metabolism in malnutrition.

questions.text: A seven-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and rash for 4 days. The rash starts on the trunk and spreads to the rest of the body and face with palms and soles spared which has a centripetal distribution. An image of the rash is given below. Which among the following is not a complication of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Meningitis:

The clinical picture with the characteristic maculopapular rash that has spread in a centripetal fashion in the image indicated the diagnosis of chickenpox caused by varicella zoster virus.

  • Patients who are at risk for complications due to this infection are:
    • Infants
    • Pregnant women
    • Immunodeficiency
    • Unvaccinated individuals
  • Complications include:
    • Bacterial infections of the skin and soft tissues in children, including Group A streptococcal infections
    • Pneumonia (option A)
    • Encephalitis (option B), cerebellar ataxia
    • Hemorrhagic complications (option D)
    • Sepsis
    • Dehydration
  • Meningitis is NOT a complication.

Incorrect options:
Option A -Varicella pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is a complication of chickenpox.

Option B - Encephalitis:

  • Encephalitis and cerebellar ataxia are complications of chickenpox.

Option D - Hemorrhage:

  • Chickenpox can lead to hemorrhagic manifestations.

questions.text: Which anatomical space is commonly associated with cholesteatoma?

choices.text: Space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus
Space next to the tensor tympani muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus:

  • Cholesteatoma commonly involves the space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus. This space is known as Prussak’s space and is susceptible to cholesteatoma formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Space between ponticulus and subiculum: This space is known as sinus tympani. It is the most common site for recurrence of cholesteatoma.

Option C- Space around the facial recess: Cholesteatoma is not commonly associated with the space around facial recess.

Option D- Space next to the tensor tympani muscle: Cholesteatoma does not typically involve the space within the tensor tympani muscle.

questions.text: The given image is associated with which type of multiple endocrine neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2B:

  • Mucosal neuromas are characterized by the presence of bumpy lips and tongue. These growths develop on the mucous membranes, which line various parts of the body, including the lips and tongue.
  • Mucosal neuromas are typically associated with conditions such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN2B), a rare genetic disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect due to the above given reason.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for the condition depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antiviral drugs with steroids: 

  • The given image shows characteristic appearance seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome(like vesical in concha area). The standard treatment for Ramsey-Hunt Syndrome involves antiviral drugs along with steroids.
     

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surgical Decompression: This condition is due to viral infection, and the focus should be on antiviral therapy along with steroids, not surgical decompression.

Option C - Topical Antibiotics: Topical antibiotics are not the recommended treatment for viral infections like Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

Option D - Supportive management: The primary treatment for Ramsay Hunt Syndrome involves antiviral drugs with steroids, not supportive treatment.

questions.text: Observe the image below and determine the group of the sample used:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A+:

  • The test depicted in the given image is a Gel Card test for blood grouping.

 

The principle involved is:

  • After mixing the patient's blood sample with specific antibodies against blood group antigens, the red blood cells (RBCs) agglutinate if they react with the corresponding antibodies. Agglutinated RBCs cannot pass through the gel due to their size; so they accumulate at the top of the gel column, forming a visible line. This line indicates a positive reaction, suggesting the presence of the specific blood group antigen on the patient's RBCs.  
  • Conversely, if the patient's RBCs do not react with the antibodies and remain unagglutinated, they can freely pass through the gel and settle at the bottom of the gel column during centrifugation. This results in the formation of a visible line at the bottom of the gel card, indicating a negative reaction, which suggests the absence of the specific blood group antigen on the patient's RBCs.
  • GIVEN THIS : the sample used in the test shown is A+

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.solution:
Correct |Option C - Degeneracy:

  • One of the characteristics of the genetic code is that it is degenerate, meaning that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.
  • The Wobble hypothesis suggests that while the first two positions of a codon and anticodon must form specific base pairs (A-U and G-C), the third position allows for flexibility or "wobble" in base pairing.
  • This flexibility explains how multiple codons can code for the same amino acid, contributing to the degeneracy of the genetic code.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Universal: Genetic code is considered universal because humans, animals, plants and bacteria all have the exact same genetic code.

Option B - Unambiguous: The genetic code is unambiguous since a codon always codes for a specific amino acid. It does not code for another amino acid.

Option D - Non-punctuate: No internal punctuation is used in the code. Thus, the code is said to be commaless. Thus once the translation of mRNA begins, the code is read in a non-contiguous fashion i.e one after the other with no breaks between them

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding German measles (rubella) is not true?

choices.text: It commonly affects children aged 3-10 years
The period of communicability extends 7 days before and 7 days after the onset of rash
German measles shows seasonal distribution, being more common in winter and early spring
The incubation period is typically 2-3 days.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The incubation period is typically 2-3 days:

  • The incubation period for German measles is typically 2-3 weeks, not days.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are true statements.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the difference between typical and atypical antipsychotics in the treatment of schizophrenia?

choices.text: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.
Atypical antipsychotics are associated with a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.
Typical antipsychotics are more likely to cause metabolic side effects such as weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia than atypical antipsychotics.
Atypical antipsychotics primarily antagonize D2 receptors, while typical antipsychotics antagonize both D2 and 5HT2A receptors.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

 

  • Typical Antipsychotics (First Generation): These medications primarily act on positive symptoms of schizophrenia, which include hallucinations, delusions, and thought disorders. They achieve this effect by antagonizing dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, reducing the excessive dopamine activity associated with positive symptoms.
  • Atypical Antipsychotics (Second Generation): In addition to addressing positive symptoms, atypical antipsychotics also target negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Negative symptoms involve deficits in cognitive and emotional functioning, such as social withdrawal, reduced motivation, and impaired attention. Atypical antipsychotics not only block dopamine receptors but also affect serotonin (5HT2A) receptors. This dual action is believed to contribute to their efficacy in addressing both positive and negative symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option B: This statement is incorrect. Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which include movement disorders like tremors and stiffness, are more commonly associated with typical antipsychotics. Atypical antipsychotics are designed to have a lower risk of causing EPS, making them preferable in some cases due to their better tolerability in terms of motor side effects.

Option C: It is incorrect because the metabolic side effects are more with the atypical antipsychotics as compared to typical antipsychotics.

Option D: It is incorrect, Atypical antipsychotics not only block dopamine D2 receptors but also affect serotonin 5HT2A receptors. This dual receptor antagonism is a key feature that contributes to their broader efficacy and improved side effect profile compared to typical antipsychotics.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists is experimenting with the effect of different types of antagonists. They take a drug and two antagonists for their experiment and draw a graph, as in the image given below, showing the log dose-response curve (DRC) of the drug alone (A) and in the presence of antagonists (B & C). Regarding their experiment, which type of antagonist do the curves B and C represent?

choices.text: B is competitive and C is noncompetitive antagonism
B is noncompetitive, and C is a competitive antagonism

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - B is competitive, and C is non-competitive antagonism:

Competitive and non-competitive antagonist:

  • Competitive antagonists compete to bind the same site on a receptor as an agonist.
  • Non-competitive antagonists bind to an allosteric site of the receptor, i.e., other than the active site.
  • In competitive antagonism, the DRC shifts towards the right, i.e., potency decreases, but efficacy remains the same.
  • On the other hand, in non-competitive antagonism, the curve becomes flat, i.e., potency remains the same, but efficacy decreases.
  • The DRC in the question shows that curve B is on the right side, representing an antagonist with the same efficacy as the drug (curve A) but is less potent.

  • So, curve B must represent a competitive antagonist.
  • On the other hand, curve C represents another antagonist with the same potency as the drug but less efficacy.
  • Therefore, curve C must represent a non-competitive antagonist.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation given above

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement about the SA node in case of a complete heart block?

choices.text: SA node doesn't cause overdrive suppression.
SA node is the gatekeeper of the heart.
SA node has the fastest impulse transmission rate.
Electrical impulses from the SA node are not conducted to the ventricles.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Electrical impulses from the SA node are not conducted to the ventricles:

  • In a complete heart block, electrical impulses from the SA node are not conducted to the ventricles.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - SA node doesn't cause overdrive suppression:

  • Overdrive suppression: Since the intrinsic rhythmicity of the SA node (60-100 impulses/min) is greater than that of the other latent pace-making sites in the heart, the firing of the SA node tends to suppress the automaticity in other loci.

Option B - SA node is the gatekeeper of the heart:

  • The 0.09-0.1s delay at the AV node is responsible for the sequential contraction of the atrium followed by ventricles; hence AV node is called the gatekeeper of the heart.

Option C - SA node has the fastest impulse transmission rate:

  • Purkinje fibers are the fast-conducting part of the heart and have an intrinsic rate of 15-40 impulses/minute.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with complaints of recurrent lower urinary tract symptoms, including painful urination, urgency, and frequent urination. He also reports intermittent fever and weight loss over the past few months. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and haematuria. Intravenous pyelography (IVP) and Cystoscopy are performed to evaluate the urinary tract and are given below.

 

Which of the following co-findings is most likely causing the patient's symptoms and matches the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Tuberculosis (TB) of the Urinary Tract

  • Renal TB can lead to the moth-eaten calyx appearance on IVP due to caseating granulomas and the golf hole appearance at the ureteric orifice during cystoscopy due to ureteric involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Renal Cell Carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma may present with hematuria and mass effect on IVP, Renal lesion with a heterogenous area of enhancement suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

Option B - Renal Calculi: Renal calculi (kidney stones) can cause flank pain and hematuria.

Stag horn calculus

Option D - Polycystic Kidney Disease: Polycystic kidney disease is characterized by multiple renal cysts, and both kidneys are enlarged.

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  •  Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD).
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a toxic nodular goiter undergoes total thyroidectomy after achieving a euthyroid state. Postoperatively, she complains of a change in voice. Which of the following is the most common nerve injury during thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - External laryngeal nerve:

  • Postoperatively, the most common nerve injured after total thyroidectomy would be the external laryngeal nerve.
  • Complications of thyroidectomy:
    • Nerve injuries
      • The most common injured nerve is the External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve ( External laryngeal nerve) due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery.
      • Leads to a loss of tension in the vocal cords with diminished power and range in the voice.
      • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - may be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not the most common nerves injured after total thyroidectomy

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the pediatrician with skin lesions on the face. On examination, you observe several small, erythematous, and crusted lesions with honey-colored crusts on the child's cheeks and around the nose. The child's mother mentions that these lesions appeared after the child had been scratching an insect bite on the face.Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Topical antibiotic ointment:

  • The most appropriate management for the described condition is topical antibiotic ointment. The clinical presentation of small, erythematous, and crusted lesions with honey-colored crusts on the child's face is consistent with impetigo. Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. The primary treatment for impetigo involves the application of topical antibiotic ointment directly on the affected areas. This helps to eliminate the bacteria and promote healing of the lesions. Commonly used topical antibiotics for impetigo include mupirocin and fusidic acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Topical corticosteroids: Topical corticosteroids are not appropriate for the management of impetigo. Corticosteroids are anti-inflammatory medications and are used to treat conditions involving inflammation, such as eczema or allergic reactions. However, impetigo is caused by a bacterial infection, and corticosteroids do not have any antibacterial properties.

Option B - Oral antifungal medication: Oral antifungal medications are used to treat fungal infections. However, impetigo is not a fungal infection but a bacterial infection. Therefore, oral antifungal medication is not the appropriate choice for the management of impetigo.

Option D - Oral antiviral medication: Oral antiviral medications are used to treat viral infections. However, impetigo is not caused by a virus but by bacteria. Therefore, oral antiviral medication is not indicated for the management of impetigo.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a tender, red, and swollen area on her forearm, showing a central area of necrosis surrounded by an erythematous halo. A skin biopsy reveals eosinophilic material forming radially arranged spikes around the necrotic center. What term describes this histological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon:

  • Histopathological staining of the biopsy shows a star-shaped body (asteroid body), and the patient's presentation is suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) is the in vivo formation of intensely eosinophilic material (radiate, star-like, asteroid or club-shaped configurations) around microorganisms (fungi, bacteria and parasites) or biologically inert substances.  

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granuloma: A granuloma is a localized area of inflammation characterized by a persistent immune stimulus that causes the accumulation of macrophages and immune cells, typically lymphocytes. Granulomas are often seen in response to chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, or foreign bodies.

Option B - Acantholysis: Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis. It is a histological feature seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, where autoantibodies target the desmosomal proteins that hold keratinocytes together. Acantholysis does not involve the deposition of eosinophilic material around a necrotic center, as described in the question.

Option D - Koebnerization: The Koebner phenomenon refers to the development of new skin lesions at the site of trauma or injury in individuals with certain skin conditions, such as psoriasis or lichen planus. It does not involve the histological findings described in the question, which focus on eosinophilic material deposition around a central necrotic area.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 3rd month post partum came to the clinic with complaints of sleeplessness, anxiety, low self worth for a week. She informed the consultant that she was unable to care for or bond with the baby. Which of the following is the diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Postpartum depression:

  • The condition mentioned in the scenario is Postpartum depression
  • This occurs within first 3-6 months
  • Characterized by insomnia, anxiety, low self worth
  • The woman is unable to care for or bond with the baby and is associated with excessive guilt and suicidal tendencies
  • This usually follows a prolonged course

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sheehan’s syndrome:

  • It is characterized by breastfeeding difficulty in the postpartum period
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis occurs usually due to torrential hemorrhage during pregnancy or childbirth as the pituitary is very sensitive to hypoxia
  • This leads to lactational failure as well as global reduction in production of pituitary hormones

Option C - Postpartum psychosis:

  • This occurs in first 2-3 weeks (<1%)
  • Characterized by severe insomnia, rapid mood swings, psychomotor restlessness, delusions, hallucinations and is associated with cognitive impairment
  • This usually presents as a psychiatric emergency

Option D - Postpartum blues:

  • These occur within first few days and resolve by 2 weeks
  • 50-60% of patients may have this
  • Primarily due to withdrawal of progesterone
  • Characterized by
    • Mild mood swings
    • Irritability
    • Anxiety
    • Decreased concentration
    • Does not want to take care of child or becomes overprotective
    • Insomnia
    • Crying spells

questions.text: A 28-year-old individual sustained severe burns involving over 50% of their body surface area due to a gas explosion.  Upon admission, the skin was charred and leathery, and the patient experienced difficulty breathing. Despite supplemental oxygen, the patient's oxygen saturation remained low. What is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Inhalation injury causing asphyxia

  • Inhalation injury occurs when a burn victim breathes in hot air, smoke, or toxic gas particles.
  • This can lead to damage in the respiratory tract, airway constriction, and inadequate oxygen intake, causing asphyxia and respiratory distress.
  • Inhalation injuries can rapidly compromise the airway and lead to death at the accident site.
  • Early intubation is thus advisable in cases of burns with possible inhalational injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Early hypovolemia: Early hypovolemia refers to the rapid loss of fluids and blood volume due to the burn injury. While hypovolemic shock is a significant concern in burn patients, it usually develops shortly after the injury and may not be the immediate cause of death at the site of the burn.

Option C- Organ failure due to sepsis: Sepsis is a severe infection that can develop as a complication of burn injuries. While sepsis is a common cause of death in burn patients, it typically occurs later in the course of treatment rather than immediately at the site of the burn.

Option D- Cardiac arrhythmias: Cardiac arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats) can result from the stress and physiological changes caused by severe burn injuries. While arrhythmias can contribute to complications in burn patients, they are unlikely to be the immediate cause of death at the site of the burn.

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Shorter menstrual cycle length

  • History of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst, and histopathological examination of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • A shorter menstrual cycle length implies more menstrual cycles, which means more menstruation and, therefore, more severe endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include:
    • Multiparity
    • Late menarche
    • OCPs
    • Smoking
    • Lactation
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Nulliparity
    • High estrogen exposure
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Low BMI
    • Family history

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Multiparity

  • Multiparity is protective for endometriosis as pregnancy and lactation imply the absence of periods for the associated period of amenorrhea.

Option B: OCPs use

  • OCPs are not risk factors for endometriosis as they reduce the net amount of estrogen in the body. Since endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic condition, it is not increased with the use of OCPs.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smoking inhibits the aromatase enzyme ( responsible for converting androgens to estrogen in the periphery), thus reducing estrogen and not increasing the risk of endometriosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on the clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3

  • 3 is the right choice since the side effects depicted involve the Trigeminal nerve ophthalmic division (V1), which supplies sensation to the forehead, scalp, and eye. 

Cluster headaches are known for one-sided pain around the eye or temple, followed by autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal blockage, and ptosis. Hemifacial pain triggered by teeth clenching is also common in trigeminal neuralgia, affecting any of its divisions but usually the maxillary or mandibular.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Is an incorrect choice since the ophthalmic nerve (V1) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (V), not the first cranial nerve (I), which is the olfactory nerve.

Option B - Is an incorrect choice since the optic nerve (II) is capable of visual work, not the symptoms described within the scenario.

Option D - Is an incorrect choice since the facial nerve (VII) supplies the muscles of facial expression and the lacrimal and salivary glands but isn't included in the sensory symptoms portrayed within the scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever and altered mental status. On examination, the patient is febrile with a temperature of 104°F (40°C). Neurological examination reveals temporal lobe involvement with memory loss. An EEG shows periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appears bloody. Which of the following diagnostic tests should be prioritized for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- PCR for HSV-1:

  • This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of HSV-1 encephalitis, characterized by fever, altered mental status, temporal lobe involvement, memory loss, and EEG findings of periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PSWC). The most suitable test for the diagnosis is PCR for HSV-1 on the CSF sample.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- MRI of the brain: is valuable for detecting specific brain abnormalities associated with encephalitis, but PCR for HSV-1 should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

Option C- CT scan of the head: may reveal structural abnormalities but is less sensitive than MRI for detecting encephalitis-related changes.

Option D- EEG with sleep deprivation: is not the primary diagnostic test for HSV-1 encephalitis. EEG findings may support the diagnosis, but PCR for HSV-1 is essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: In a physiology seminar, a professor explains different types of membrane receptors. He explains that membrane proteins are divided into integral proteins and peripheral proteins. GPCR (G Protein Coupled Receptor) is an example of an integral protein present in the cell membrane. Which among the following statements is true of integral proteins?

choices.text: Are not attached to the outer leaflet
Are not attached to the inner leaflet
Van der Waals forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer
Electrostatic forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Van der Waals forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer:

  • Integral proteins, including GPCRs, are embedded within the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. The attachment is facilitated by hydrophobic interactions and van der Waals forces, between the hydrophobic regions of the integral proteins and the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Are not attached to the outer leaflet: This statement is incorrect. Integral proteins are indeed attached to the lipid bilayer, and they span the membrane from the outer to the inner leaflet.

Option B – Are not attached to the inner leaflet: This statement is incorrect. Integral proteins span the entire lipid bilayer, being embedded in both the outer and inner leaflets.

Option D – Electrostatic forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer: This statement is incorrect. Electrostatic forces are responsible for the attachment of peripheral proteins with the integral proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is associated with impaired sodium reabsorption and presents with symptoms similar to hypoaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - ENaC channel mutation:

  • Pseudohypoaldosteronism-Ⅰ is characterized by impaired sodium reabsorption due to mutations in the ENaC (Epithelial Sodium Channel) gene.
  • This condition presents similarly to hypoaldosteronism, leading to electrolyte imbalances and symptoms such as dehydration and metabolic acidosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aquaporin-2 mutation: Aquaporin-2 mutations are associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, not impaired sodium reabsorption.

Option C - ROMK channel mutation and Option D - NKCC2 transporter mutation: They are associated with other forms of renal tubular disorders, not pseudohypoaldosteronism-Ⅰ.

questions.text:
The features in the table below describe the most common benign bony tumor. Match the features accordingly.


	
		
			
			1. Gross appearance
			
			
			a. Cartilaginous cap
			
		
		
			
			2. Epiphyseal tumor
			
			
			b. Carrot shaped ulna
			
		
		
			
			3. Diaphyseal aclasis
			
			
			c. Wide curettage and bone grafting
			
		
		
			
			4. Xray finding
			
			
			d. Cauliflower appearance
			
		
		
			
			5. Treatment
			
			
			e. Multiple exostosis
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			f. Excision
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			g. Trevor's disease
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - 1-d, 2-g, 3-e, 4-b, 5-f:

The most common benign bony tumor is osteochondroma.

1. Gross appearance d. Cauliflower appearance
2.Epiphyseal tumor g. Trevor's disease
3. Diaphyseal aclasis e. Multiple exostosis
4. Xray finding b. Carrot shaped ulna (the cartilaginous cap is better seen in MRI)
5. Treatment f. Exision

 

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female came to the clinic with complaints of skin lesions and painful knee joints for 1 week. On examination, guttate lesions and arthritis of the knee and distal interphalangeal joints were seen. She was given NSAIDs. Which of the following is not a clinical feature of the condition characterized by guttate lesions, arthritis of the joints, and managed with NSAIDs?

choices.text: Distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is not involved in Psoriasis
Arthritis mutilans is a severe form of Psoriatic arthritis in which bone resorption happens.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) is not involved in Psoriasis:

  • This is an incorrect characteristic of Psoriatic arthritis
  • The correct characteristic is that distal interphalangeal joints are the characteristic of Psoriatic arthritis

Incorrect Options

Option A, C & D:

  • These are the characteristics of psoriatic arthritis
