questions.text: A public health conference is being organized in a rural community to address various health issues prevalent in the region. As a community medicine healthcare provider, you are tasked with educating local healthcare workers about effective communication strategies for health promotion. During your session, you discuss different communication methods, including Socratic communication, to engage the audience and facilitate learning. Which among the following is not an example of Socratic communication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lecture:

  • Lectures primarily involve one-way communication where the speaker imparts knowledge without much interaction or engagement from the audience.
  • It is a form of didactic communication.
  • Socratic communication, on the other hand, emphasizes dialogue, questioning, and critical thinking to stimulate learning and understanding.
  • Example: Suppose there is a community, where there is a problem of domestic violence. To find out why this is happening, one can either do quantitative study design or qualitative.
    • Meaning, one can frame a questionnaire, where they can put 20 close ended questions such as are you a victim of domestic abuse, what is the reason, why is it happening, etc.
    • So, as an answer one will get it in numbers like 20 women say that husband drinks and beats them, 30 women say that family has expectations. So, this way one gets an answer in numbers.
  • Therefore, a lecture is NOT an example of Socratic communication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Panel discussion:

  • A panel discussion involves a group of experts who discuss a particular topic in front of an audience.
  • In a panel discussion, the moderator typically poses questions to the panelists, who then engage in dialogue, exchange ideas, and provide insights based on their expertise.
  • It is a form of two-way communication.
  • This format encourages interactive communication and critical thinking, making it an example of Socratic communication.

Option B - Symposium:

  • A symposium is a formal gathering where experts present their research or ideas on a specific topic.
  • It often includes a series of presentations followed by discussions or Q&A sessions.
  • While symposiums can vary in format, they typically promote dialogue and exchange of ideas among participants, resembling the principles of Socratic communication.

Option D - Workshop:

  • A workshop is an interactive session where participants engage in hands-on activities, discussions, and exercises to learn new skills or concepts.
  • Workshops often encourage active participation, problem-solving, and collaboration among participants, which are consistent with the principles of Socratic communication.

questions.text: Which tapeworm species is leaf-like, lacks suckers, and has two grooves ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Diphyllobothrium latum:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum is characterized by its leaf-like appearance.
  • It lacks suckers on its scolex.
  • Instead of suckers, it possesses two suctorial grooves, also known as bothria, which are longitudinal channels used for attachment to the host's intestine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Taenia solium: Taenia solium, also known as the pork tapeworm, has suckers and hooks, which are used for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have a leaf-like appearance and does not possess two grooves.

Option B- Taenia saginata: Taenia saginata, known as the beef tapeworm, is similar to Taenia solium in that it has suckers but no hooks for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have the leaf-like characteristics or the presence of two grooves.

Option C- Echinococcus: Echinococcus tapeworms, specifically Echinococcus granulosus and Echinococcus multilocularis, are known for their small size and the formation of cysts in various organs of the host, such as the liver and lungs. It possesses both suckers and hooks. They do not have a leaf-like appearance or two grooves.

questions.text: Which of the following is the other use of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy other than detecting ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - To detect TB:

  • The other use of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy is to detect TB
  • It is performed around days 20 to 24 under general or local anesthesia
  • Intercourse should be avoided the whole month in which the premenstrual endometrial biopsy is scheduled to avoid the risk of accidental abortion
  • It is done to check secretory changes: If the secretory changes are present then we know that ovulation occurred.
    • Check adequate secretory changes: For every day of the month endometrial changes are different
    • Luteal phase defect (reason for infertility): When the difference between expected and observed changes is ≥ 2 days

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not the other uses of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is correctly represented by the graph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Growth hormone:

  • GH secretion occurs in a pulsatile pattern, characterized by fluctuations in secretion levels.

Stimulate Growth Hormone Secretion

Inhibit Growth Hormone Secretion
  • Decreased blood glucose level
  • Decreased blood free fatty acid levels
  • Increased blood amino acid levels (arginine)
  • Starvation or fasting, protein deficiency
  • Trauma, stress, excitement
  • Exercise
  • Testosterone, estrogen
  • Deep sleep (stages 2 and 4 )
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • Ghrelin
  • Increased blood glucose level
  • Increased blood free fatty acid levels
  • Aging
  • Obesity
  • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (somatostatin)
  • Growth hormone (exogenous)
  • Insulin-like growth factors (somatomedins)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin secretion peaks after meals, followed by a rapid decline in plasma levels. It circulates mainly in an unbound form with a short plasma half-life of about 6 minutes, cleared within 10 to 15 minutes.

Option B - Cortisol:

  • Cortisol secretion is stimulated by ACTH. Levels of corticotrophin-releasing hormone, ACTH, and cortisol are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. Plasma cortisol levels peak around 20 μg/dl before arising in the morning and decrease to about 5 μg/dl around midnight due to cyclical signals from the hypothalamus.

Option D - Thyroid:

  • TSH and TRH regulate thyroid hormone secretion. TSH levels are low during the day and increase at night, controlling the release of thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormone secretion doesn't follow a pulsatile pattern and doesn't acutely change in response to heavy exercise.

questions.text: What medication was most likely prescribed to a 20-year-old male experiencing erectile dysfunction, leading to subsequent symptoms of hypotension and blue-green color blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors:

  • The drug Sildenafil was responsible for patient’s condition.
  • Sildenafil is phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors.
  • Side effects of sildenafil
    • Headache
    • Blue green color blindness
    • Hypotension

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • Alprostadil, Pentolamine, Apomorphine are other drugs used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction but they do not cause the given side fefects.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis where slit lamp examination reveals bilateral corneal deposits arranged in a whorl-like pattern in a female with a history of long-term usage of indomethacin for rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vortex keratopathy:

  • Vortex keratopathy, also known as corneal verticillata or whorl keratopathy, is characterized by the deposition of medications(drugs) or other substances in a vortex or whorl-like pattern on the corneal epithelium. It is commonly associated with the long-term use of certain medications, such as indomethacin, amiodarone, chloroquine, and tamoxifen. The corneal deposits in vortex keratopathy are usually asymptomatic but can cause blurred vision and sensitivity to light in some case

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a viral infection caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. It typically presents with a painful rash, vesicles, and redness in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Corneal involvement in herpes zoster ophthalmicus can manifest as dendritic ulcers or geographic lesions, rather than the characteristic whorl-like pattern seen in vortex keratopathy. Therefore, this is not the most likely diagnosis in the given scenario.

Option C - Keratoconjunctivitis sicca: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye syndrome, is a condition characterized by inadequate production of aqueous layer of tear film, leading to ocular surface dryness and irritation. It commonly presents with symptoms of dryness, grittiness, and blurred vision. Although dry eye syndrome can cause corneal changes and opacities, they do not typically exhibit the specific whorl-like pattern observed in vortex keratopathy. Therefore, this is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Option D - Band keratopathy: Band keratopathy is a condition characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the cornea, typically in a horizontal band-like pattern. It commonly occurs in conditions associated with hypercalcemia or long-standing uveitis. The corneal deposits in band keratopathy are usually seen in the mid-peripheral or peripheral cornea, rather than the characteristic whorl-like pattern seen in vortex keratopathy. Hence, this is not the most likely diagnosis in the given scenario.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a month-long fever and dry cough, along with hemoptysis and myalgias for one week. His chest x-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe. With a history of treated tuberculosis, the doctor suggests tissue culture of bronchoalveolar lavage with methenamine silver stain. Microscopic examination reveals specific features. What features are indicated, and what might the organism be?

choices.text: Fungi is showing acute angle branching with septate filament and is aspergillus
Fungi is showing non-septate acute angle branching and is candida
Fungi showing right angle branching with septa and is mucor
Fungi is showing non-septate acute angle branching and is aspergillus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fungi is showing acute angle branching with septate filament and is aspergillus:

  • Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes invasive disease in immunocompromised human beings. It can cause a variety of clinical syndromes:
    • Allergic bronchi pulmonary aspergillosis is a condition in which inhaled spores provoke a hypersensitivity reaction.
    • Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis: In this condition, the fungus grows within the bronchioles' lumen, where fungal plugs may occur.
    • Aspergilloma: A fungal ball that grows within and is usually restricted to an existing lung cavity, for example, due to old tuberculosis or bronchiectasis.
    • Invasive aspergillosis: The fungus first causes pneumonia and later disseminates to involve other organs, for example, the brain, kidney or heart. Patients who develop this disease are usually immunocompromised, and it could be fatal.
  • Tissue sections biopsy: Septate dichotomously branching hyphae at an acute angle (45 degrees) is characteristic of aspergillus infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fungi showing non-septate acute angle branching and is candida:

  • When the candida is microscopically examined in KOH: pseudohyphae, true hyphae and budding yeasts are seen in tissue culture.
  • They form pseudohyphae and budding yeasts at 20°C while germ tubes at 37°C.

Option C - Fungi showing right angle branching with septa and is mucor:

  • In biopsy specimens of tissues infected with mucor: organisms are seen microscopically as non-septate hyphae with broad, irregular walls and branches that form more or less at right angles (about 90 degrees).

questions.text: A 70-year old male presented with blood in urine, urinary urgency, hesitancy with a weak stream, and low-grade but constant back pain. Digital rectal examination revealed an enlarged prostate gland with several nodules. Biopsy results showed adenocarcinoma and MRI report revealed stage 4 carcinoma. Surgery is advised for symptomatic relief. What type of surgery is indicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TURP surgery:

  • The old aged patient with stage T4 carcinoma who presents urinary symptoms is advised to undergo least invasive surgery.
  • T4 is usually managed with hormonal ablation and radiotherapy. Still, if there are lower urinary tract symptoms, the patient must be treated with palliative surgery of transurethral resection of the prostate.
  • The TURP is the surgical procedure in which a 26Fr resectoscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder. Cysto-urethroscopy is done. The prostate is assessed for size. Strips of tissues are cut from the bladder neck using a diathermy loop. First median lobe and then lateral lobes are resected afterwards. The Ellik evacuator evacuates pieces of the prostate to pass to the bladder.
  • It is accompanied by other treatments such as medical treatment (LHRH agonists) and radiotherapy to manage metastatic deposits, especially in bones.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Millin prostatectomy

  • It is done using a retropubic approach that may cause disturbances in many patients.
  • It is usually indicated in benign prostatic hyperplasia with very large adenoma ( > 75ml)

Option C: Freyer’s prostatectomy

  • Freyer’s suprapubic prostatectomy uses the transvesical approach to remove the prostate gland.
  • It is preferred for patients having bladder stones and bladder diverticulum.

Option D: Young’s prostatectomy

  • Young’s prostatectomy uses a perineal approach. It is not preferred by urologists nowadays.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the longest acting Nitroimidazoles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Secnidazole:

  • Nitroimidazole drugs are
    • Metronidazole
    • Ornidazole
    • Tinidazole
    • Satranidazole
    • Secnidazole
  • Among Nitroimidazole drugs,Secnidazole is the longest acting drug.
  • MOA:
    • Inside the bacteria, they produce Nitric oxide free radicals
      • Cause DNA damage
      • Inhibit PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) and causes DNA damage

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented to the clinic with complaints of a submandibular mass for the past 2 months. The mass is soft and nontender. Examination of the oral cavity shows a unilateral translucent swelling in the floor of the mouth, lateral to the midline. Which of the following is true regarding this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland
It is the most common type of minor salivary gland tumor

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is a mucous extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland:

  • This patient presented with a submandibular swelling that is soft and nontender. Examination showed a translucent swelling on the floor of the mouth. This presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of ranula.
  • The term ranula is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.
  • It is mostly caused due to local trauma and duct rupture (i.e. during tongue piercing), followed by mucin spillage into the surrounding soft tissues. It can also rarely be caused by obstruction due to a sialolith or a mucus plug.
  • Ranula is present on the floor of the mouth. It is usually unilateral and lateral to the midline. It is a smooth, dome-shaped, fluctuating, and painless swelling.
  • The size of a ranula varies from a few to several centimeters in diameter. Very large lesions may occupy the entire floor of the mouth.
  • Histopathological features include mucin accumulation surrounded by granulation and fibrous tissue (mucous extravasation phenomenon) or a cyst filled with mucin and lined by the ductal epithelium (mucus retention cyst)
  • Diagnosis is usually made clinically, but MRI can be used in atypical cases. Treatment involves surgical removal of the cyst or marsupialization of the cyst.
  • Removal of the ranula can be tricky as there is a high risk of damaging the submandibular duct during ranula surgery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It is treated with chemotherapy:

  • Chemotherapy can be used in some cases of carcinomas of the oral cavity. A tumor presents as a hard, fixed mass, unlike this patient, who presented with a soft, non-tender mass.

Option C - It is the most common type of minor salivary gland tumor:

  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common minor salivary gland tumor and is present most commonly on the palate. This patient's presentation is not consistent with a minor salivary gland tumor.

Option D - It is diagnosed by biopsy:

  • A ranula is diagnosed clinically. MRI can be used in patients with atypical presentations. A biopsy is not required.

questions.text: In a community medicine study assessing the efficacy of a new vaccination program, researchers aim to determine if the program reduces the incidence of a specific infectious disease in a population. They set the significance level (α) at 0.05. During analysis, they discover a statistically significant decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals compared to the control group. However, upon further investigation, it is found that the decrease in disease incidence is not actually attributable to the vaccination program. Which of the following is not true about Type 1 error?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but rejected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The null hypothesis is false but rejected:

  • The correct statement would be: “The null hypothesis is true but rejected.”
  • Type 1 error means stating that there is an effect or difference when none exists (H0 incorrectly rejected in favor of H1).

 

Reality

H1

H0

Study rejects H0

Power (1-β)

Type 1 error (α)

Study does not reject H0

Type 2 error (β)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - α error:

  • α error refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In this case, the researchers set the significance level (α) at 0.05, indicating the threshold for accepting or rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, α error is related to this scenario.

Option B - False positive trial:

  • A false positive trial occurs when the intervention appears effective, but in reality, it does not have the intended effect. In this scenario, the apparent decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals constitutes a false positive result because the vaccination program is not the cause of the observed reduction.

Option C - Serious error:

  • Type 1 is a serious error in hypothesis testing as it can lead to incorrect conclusions and potentially harmful decisions, such as implementing an ineffective intervention or treatment.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female, P1L1, underwent a routine pap smear, which was reported as CIN III (High-Grade Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion/ HSIL). The colposcopy showed an area of abnormal cells around her cervix. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Colposcopy biopsy

  • A colposcopy is recommended if cervical screening finds cell HPV-induced cell changes.
  • These dysplastic cells can turn into cervical cancer cells.
  • Colposcopy is a procedure that examines the cervix for abnormal tissue and takes a biopsy if needed.
  • If CIN III is found, the next step is a colposcopy-directed biopsy for tissue diagnosis and to plan further management

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Trachelectomy

  • Surgical removal of the cervix, is called trachelectomy.
  • Trachelectomy is done in younger women with early cervix cancer (with a tumor no larger than 2-3 centimeters).
  • Trachelectomy need not be done in premalignant lesions in a young female unless a biopsy proves invasive carcinoma.

Option B: Hysterectomy

  • A hysterectomy is not done for CIN III unless a biopsy proves cancer

Option C: Conization

  • Conization of the cervix is defined as the excision of a cone-shaped or cylindrical wedge from the cervix uteri that includes the transformation zone and all or a portion of the endocervical canal.
  • Conization is not done in a young patient with an incomplete family as it causes
    • Short cervix→ cervical incompetence → abortions
    • Stenosis→ Infertility

questions.text: Which of the following features is true about feigned insanity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Exaggerated facial appearance: 

  • In cases of feigned insanity, the person voluntarily exaggerates the facial appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gradual onset: In feigned insanity, its Sudden onset.

Option B - Presence of predisposing factor: Predisposing factors are absent in feigned insanity.

Option D - Motive is usually absent: In feigned insanity, Motive is always present.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female arrives at the emergency department with her friend. She slipped and fell down a flight of stairs, hitting her head on the ground. Which of the following vessels will most likely be injured due to trauma on the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Middle meningeal artery:

  • The marked area in the image is Pterion.
  • It is the 'H' shaped point where frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones meet.
  • The anterior division of the middle meningeal artery lies under this point and is vulnerable to damage due to trauma leading to extradural hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Internal carotid artery:

  • The internal carotid artery is one of the main arterial supplies of the brain. It does not lie beneath the Pterion and is not damaged due to trauma at this point.

Option C - Anterior cerebral artery:

  • Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery supplying the anterior cerebrum. It does not lie beneath the Pterion.

Option D - Deep temporal artery:

  • The deep temporal arteries (anterior, middle and posterior) are the branches of the second part of the maxillary artery.
  • This artery is damaged due to traumatic injury of the zygomatic arch, not the Pterion.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Astrocytes
			
			
			A
			
			
			Formation of the myelin sheath in CNS
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Oligodendrocytes
			
			
			B
			
			
			Formation of Blood Brain Barrier (BBB)
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Ependymal cells
			
			
			C
			
			
			Formation of Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-B, 2-A, 3-C:

  1. Astrocytes - Formation of Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB): Astrocytes are a type of glial cell in the central nervous system (CNS) that forms the blood-brain barrier (BBB). They form tight junctions with endothelial cells of the capillaries, regulating the passage of substances between the bloodstream and the brain.
  2. Oligodendrocytes - Formation of the myelin sheath in CNS: Oligodendrocytes are another type of glial cell in the CNS responsible for producing the myelin sheath, which wraps around axons of neurons. This myelin sheath serves to insulate the axons.
  3. Ependymal cells - Formation of Cerebrospinal fluid: Ependymal cells are involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which cushions the brain and spinal cord, provides buoyancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. Blood pressure on admission is 190/110 mmHg. After initial stabilization, a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is suspected. Which of the following medications is considered the best option for preoperative hypertension management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phenoxybenzamine:

  • Phenoxybenzamine: This is a non-selective alpha-blocker and is considered the best drug for the preoperative management of hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma.
  • It irreversibly blocks alpha-adrenergic receptors, preventing vasoconstriction caused by catecholamines released by the tumor. It is used to control blood pressure and reduce the risk of hypertensive crisis during surgery.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Propranolol: While a beta-blocker, propranolol is contraindicated in pheochromocytoma until alpha blockade is achieved. If given without alpha blockade, unopposed alpha stimulation can worsen hypertension and lead to a hypertensive crisis.
  • Option B - Hydralazine: This is a direct-acting vasodilator and is not the first-line choice for preoperative management of pheochromocytoma. Alpha blockade is preferred.
  • Option D - Amlodipine: This is a calcium channel blocker, not typically used in the immediate management of pheochromocytoma-related hypertension. Alpha blockade is the primary approach.

questions.text: Which arteries contribute to the plexus that is a common site for anterior epistaxis in children?

choices.text: Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, nasal branch of anterior superior dental artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery:

Kiesselbach's plexus, also known as Little's area, is a vascular plexus located in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum. It is a common site for epistaxis particularly in children. The plexus is formed by the anastomosis of four arteries.:

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine artery
  • Greater palatine artery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery.:

  • The posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of Kiesselbach's plexus. The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and supplies the nasal septum as well as the lateral wall of the nose.

Option C - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery.:

  • The superior labial artery and the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

Option D - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule:

Anterior ethmoidal artery, nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, greater palatine artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery.

  • The nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought to the clinic by his father complaining of short stature. On examination, triangular facies were noticed. The child is diagnosed with Alagille syndrome. Which of the following is not a clinical feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Blue sclera:

  • The condition described in the scenario is Alagille syndrome
  • It is characterized by Neonatal cholestasis, Triangular facies (also seen in Russell silver syndrome), Pulmonary stenosis, Butterfly vertebrae, and short stature
  • The blue sclera is not a feature of this syndrome

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are the features of Alagille syndrome

questions.text: A 48-year-old male came complaining of odynophagia. On endoscopy, shallow punched-out ulcers with a few vesicles are seen on the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Herpes simplex esophagitis:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection .
  • Endoscopic findings reveal shallow erosions or ulcers(punched-out lesions) and vesicles, typically involving the lower third of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CMV esophagitis:

  • CMV endoscopy would show deep ulcers, most commonly in the middle third of the esophagus.

Option B - Candida esophagitis:

  • Esophageal candidiasis Endoscopy would show white plaques on the esophageal mucosa.

Option C - Corrosive esophagitis:

  • Corrosive esophagitis is characterized by Esophageal bleeding, perforation, or stricture can be worsened by high-degree corrosive esophagitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1L1 at 34 weeks of pregnancy presents with high-grade fever with chills and rigor. Her CBC shows Hb 8.8 gm%, TLC 10,500 platelet count 1.8 lakhs, malarial parasite slide positive for plasmodium vivax, and liver and renal functions are normal. USG shows a single live fetus with normal parameters and liquor. Which is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Chloroquine

  • Chloroquine is considered safe for use in pregnancy and is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women.
  • It is effective against the asexual erythrocytic forms of the parasite.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Mefloquine

  • Mefloquine is generally avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy due to potential concerns. However, it may be considered in the second and third trimesters if other options are unavailable or ineffective.
  • Its safety in pregnancy is not well-established, and it is not considered a first-line option.

Option C: Artesunate

  • Artesunate is effective against severe malaria and is generally considered safe in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.
  • It is recommended for severe malaria, but for uncomplicated cases, other options like chloroquine are preferred.

Option D: Lumefantrine

  • It is used in pregnancy to treat malaria for complicated cases requiring ACT (Artemisinin Combination Therapy).
  • Limited data available regarding the safety profile of artemisinins in early pregnancy.
  • They are, therefore, not recommended by WHO as the first-line treatment for malaria in the first trimester due to associated embryo-fetal toxicity in animal studies.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics inhibits the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Tetracycline:

  • Tetracycline inhibits protein synthesis by blocking the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.
  • This action prevents the incorporation of amino acids into growing peptide chains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibiting peptidyl transferase activity. It does not specifically target the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.

Option C - Linezolid: Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by attaching to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit, preventing the formation of the initiation complex. It does not directly interfere with the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.

Option D - Aminoglycoside: Aminoglycosides bind to the 30S ribosomal subunit and interfere with the proofreading process of mRNA translation, leading to the misreading of the genetic code. While they can inhibit initiation of protein synthesis, their primary mechanism involves interfering with translation elongation and proofreading, rather than specifically targeting the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site.

questions.text: What is the base sequence of RNA formed from the template strand during mRNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: CGGUAAAGCUUA

DNA and RNA:

  • DNA is the basic unit of life. At the same time, RNA is involved in the synthesis of proteins.
  • DNA is deoxyribonucleic acid, while RNA is ribonucleic acid.
  • DNA is divided into nuclear DNA and mitochondrial DNA. Transfer RNA, messenger RNA, and ribosomal RNA are the main types of RNA.
  • The bases present in DNA are adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine. In RNA, thymine is replaced by uracil.
  • DNA is a double-stranded structure, while RNA is single-stranded.
  • DNA contains an antiparallel helix while RNA structure is a hairpin and loops.
  • The process by which DNA is converted into RNA is known as transcription.
  • During this process, the coding strand, also known as the template strand of DNA, is used to synthesize RNA.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil.

Incorrect options

Option B: AUUCGAAAUGGC

  • It does not show the transcription of the non-template stand shown above.
  • Therefore, this is not the right answer.

Option C: GCCATTTCGAAT

  • This sequence shows the template strand and not the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

Option D: UAAGCUUUACCG

  • This sequence does not show the translation of the non-template strand.
  • The direction of new RNA is always the same as the non-template strand; however, the thymine is replaced by uracil during transcription.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a family history of MEN2 presents with an intermittent and severe headache, palpitations, and excessive sweating. A palpable mass is detected in his upper left abdomen during the physical examination and his blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Plasma fractionated metanephrine
level:

  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically arising from the adrenal medulla. Pheochromocytomas can cause paroxysmal hypertension, severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. The presence of a palpable mass in the left upper abdomen further supports this diagnosis.
  • Measurement of plasma-free metanephrines is the most sensitive and specific initial test for detecting pheochromocytomas. Plasma-free metanephrines (metanephrine and normetanephrine) are the breakdown products of catecholamines and are elevated in the setting of a pheochromocytoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen: It is a valuable imaging modality to localize the tumor once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is confirmed. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice.

Option B - A 24-hour urine collection for vanillylmandelic acid (VMA): It is an older test that measures the breakdown product of epinephrine and norepinephrine. Although it can be used in the workup of pheochromocytoma, it is less sensitive and specific compared to plasma-free metanephrines.

Option D - MRI of the abdomen: It can provide detailed anatomical information about the tumor and surrounding structures. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice in this scenario.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency departmentwith a complaint of blood in urine for last one hour. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/60mmHg, pulse rate is 110/minute, and fullness in his left loin. On history, he reports that on the same day in the morning, he played rugby. After that, he passed frank blood in his urine. He also feels mild discomfort in his left loin. What is the diagnosis related to the above-mentioned patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Congenital Hydronephrosis

  • Clinical signs: The above mentioned 20-year-old patient developed hematuria following minor trauma while playing rugby. He was completely unaware of the trauma and surprised to have hematuria. He did notice mild left loin discomfort. Hematuria following minor trauma typically occurs in a pathological kidney.
  • In a healthy young man, this would be a congenital hydronephrosis (sometimes called idiopathic hydronephrosis) from a pelvic-ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction that has ruptured with urinary extravasation, the cause of fullness in his left loin.
  • This patient needs resuscitation, although he is probably stable from the cardiovascular point of view but for his tachycardia. He needs an IVU to make sure that the other kidney is normal.
  • Congenital hydronephrosis (CH) is a clinically significant genitourinary congenital disability identified by the demonstration of dilated renal pelvis and calyx.
  • Symptoms of hydronephrosis usually depend on the cause. About 69% of affected infants develop abnormal renal function or require corrective surgery.
  • Often there are no symptoms,Symptoms may include-- sudden or severe flank pain, nausea, frequent urination or painful urination, weakness, fever due to urinary tract infection and hematuria.

Option A: Renal Cell Cancer

  • Renal cell cancer is one of the most common renal cancers in adults.
  • In the early stages, patients remain symptoms free, while after the progression of the disease,patient can present with lump in the abdomen, hematuria, weight loss, fatigue and persistent pain in the abdomen.

Option B: Adenocarcinoma

  • Adenocarcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in the glands that line the organs and can occur almost anywhere in the body.
  • Adenocarcinoma usually arises in mucous membranes and initially appears as thickened, white, patchy mucous membranes.

Option D: Pyonephrosis

 

  • Pyonephrosis is a pyogenic infection of the upper urinary tract due to ureteral obstruction.
  • It is usually associated with suppurative lesions of the renal parenchyma and loss of renal function. Patients are most often symptomatic but remain asymptomatic in 15% of cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent abortions and absent fetal movements in her previous pregnancy. Workup reveals a positive VDRL test. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and which antibody is the most specific for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) - Lupus anticoagulant:

  • The clinical scenario described, including recurrent abortions, absent fetal movements, and a positive VDRL test, is highly suggestive of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS).
  • Patients who have certain antiphospholipid antibodies may have false positive VDRL test. This occurs because the aPL bind to the lipids in the test and make it come out positive.
  • APS is characterized by the presence of lupus anticoagulant, along with other antibodies such as anti-cardiolipin antibody and anti-β2-glycoprotein antibody.
  • The lupus anticoagulant is associated with an increased risk of thrombotic events and pregnancy complications. 

Clinical Criteria

Lab Criteria

1. Vascular thrombosis

1. Anti-Cardiolipin IgG/IgM

2. Pregnancy Morbidity

2. Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein 1 (GP1)

3. Death of normal fetus at 3-10 weeks

3. Lupus anticoagulant (LAC)

4. Premature birth at ≤34 weeks due to preeclampsia

4. Medium to high titer

5. 3 consecutive abortions at <10 weeks

5. At least 2 times, 12 weeks apart

6. Placental insufficiency at <34 weeks

 

Based on these classification criteria, patients who have at least one positive clinical and one positive laboratory criteria are considered to have a diagnosis of APS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) - Anti-dsDNA antibody: SLE is an autoimmune disease characterized by various manifestations, including lupus nephritis and lupus cerebritis. The presence of anti-dsDNA antibody is highly specific for SLE and correlates with disease activity.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis - Rheumatoid factor: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. Rheumatoid factor is an antibody commonly found in the blood of individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not specific to this condition.

Option D - Sjogren's syndrome - Anti-SSA/Ro antibody: Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the salivary glands and tear ducts. Anti-SSA/Ro antibody is commonly found in individuals with Sjogren's syndrome but is not as specific as lupus anticoagulant in the diagnosis of APS.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is preferred due to its high potency and ability to cross the blood-brain barrier, leading to rapid onset and short duration of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Fentanyl

  • Fentanyl is an opioid analgesic known for its high potency and rapid onset of action. It is approximately 100 times more potent than morphine and has the ability to cross the blood-brain barrier more efficiently, leading to a rapid onset of action. This makes it highly effective in managing acute pain, particularly in settings like surgery or in the treatment of severe pain in cancer patients.

  • High Potency: Fentanyl is significantly more potent than other opioids such as morphine.
  • Blood-Brain Barrier: Fentanyl's lipophilic nature allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier quickly, leading to a faster onset of effects.
  • Short Duration: Despite its rapid onset, fentanyl has a short duration of action, making it useful in situations where quick pain relief is needed but with control over the duration of its effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Morphine:

  • While effective, morphine has a slower onset of action and does not cross the blood-brain barrier as quickly as fentanyl.

Option C - Sufentanyl:

  • Although more potent than fentanyl, Sufentanil is typically used in more controlled settings like anesthesia due to its potency and pharmacokinetics.

Option D - Meperidine:

  • Meperidine is less potent than fentanyl and has a longer duration of action, with less efficiency in crossing the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents for a screening mammogram. The mammogram shows a well-defined oval mass with microcalcifications within the lesion. No architectural distortion is noted. The surrounding breast tissue appears normal, and there are no axillary lymphadenopathies. According to the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS), what is the most appropriate BIRADS category for this mammographic finding?

choices.text: BIRADS Category 5: Highly suggestive of malignancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: BIRADS Category 5

  • Highly suggestive of malignancy: This category is used for mammographic findings that have features highly indicative of malignancy. The  well-defined oval mass with microcalcifications fits the criteria of 5 category, as the presence of microcalcifications within a mass is a worrisome sign.

BIRADS 5 

  • A dense lesion generally
  •  It is white and microcalcification that is a feature of breast cancer less than 0.5 mm
  • There can be architectural distortions because of cancer causing desmoplastic reactions.
  • Focal asymmetry is also seen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BIRADS Category 2: Benign finding: This category is assigned to mammographic findings that have typical benign features with no suspicious features. It does not include any lesions with microcalcifications, as microcalcifications warrant further evaluation.

Option B - BIRADS Category 3: Probably benign finding: This category is used for mammographic findings with a high likelihood of being benign, but the radiologist recommends a short-term follow-up for further assessment. 

Option C - BIRADS Category 4: Probably Malignant: This category is used for mammographic findings that have suspicious features but are not highly suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A neutropenic patient who recently underwent chemotherapy presents with fever, right lower quadrant tenderness, and bloody diarrhea. Imaging reveals a thickened cecal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis, and when is surgical intervention indicated?

choices.text: Typhlitis; indicated if no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotics
Crohn's disease; indicated if perforation leads to peritonitis
Ischemic colitis; indicated if imaging shows bowel necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Typhlitis; indicated if no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotics:

  • The clinical presentation of fever, right lower quadrant tenderness, bloody diarrhea, and a thickened cecal wall on imaging is highly suggestive of typhlitis, also known as neutropenic colitis.
  • In typhlitis, medical management with antibiotics is the mainstay of treatment. Surgical intervention is warranted if there is no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy or if perforation occurs, which can lead to peritonitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diverticulitis; indicated if perforation occurs:

  • Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis typically presents with left lower quadrant pain and is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention for diverticulitis is indicated if perforation occurs but is not solely based on the clinical scenario described.

Option C - Crohn's disease; indicated if perforation leads to peritonitis:

  • Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease presents with various symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally fever, but it is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention in Crohn's disease is typically based on complications such as strictures or fistulas, rather than acute perforation.

Option D - Ischemic colitis; indicated if imaging shows bowel necrosis:

  • Ischemic colitis: Ischemic colitis presents with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea but is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention in ischemic colitis may be indicated if there is evidence of bowel necrosis, but this is not mentioned in the clinical scenario provided.

questions.text: Which of the following radio-isotope has the highest half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radium-226:

  • Radium-226 has the highest half-life (1600 years). The first radioisotope used in humans was Radium-226. It produces Radon (decay compound), which causes carcinoma of the lungs. It emits alpha, beta, and gamma rays.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cesium-137: Cesium-137 has a half-life of about 30 years.

Option C - Cobalt-60: Cobalt-60 has a half-life of about 5.26 years.

Option D - Fluorine-18: Fluorine-18 has a very short half-life of about 2 hours.

questions.text: Hospitalization for seizures post-immunization in children comes under which classification of a vaccine reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serious reaction:

  • Any hospitalization post vaccinization comes under serious reaction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A and B: Both options are the same. They usually include local pain, fever, and redness.

Option D - Severe reaction:These reactions can be treated on an OPD basis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and frequent urination. He reports having to wake up multiple times during the night to urinate, and his urine output during the day seems abnormally high. Laboratory investigations reveal a urine output exceeding 3 liters per day. Radiograph image is given below, what is the first line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Desmopressin acetate (DDAVP):

  • Desmopressin is the synthetic analog of vasopressin and is the first-line treatment for central diabetes insipidus, as it helps to reduce excessive urination and thirst.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is not typically used as a first-line treatment for central diabetes insipidus. It is a diuretic medication that may exacerbate symptoms by increasing urine output.

Option C - Amiloride: Amiloride is not typically used as a first-line treatment for central diabetes insipidus. It is a potassium-sparing diuretic that may not address the underlying cause of excessive urination and thirst.

Option D - Furosemide: Thiazides are treatment choice for nephrogenic DI.

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops from the structure marked?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Median umbilical ligament:

  • The marked structure is the allantois, a hindgut diverticulum. It forms the urachus during fetal development, connecting the bladder apex to the umbilicus, which later degenerates into the median umbilical ligament. This ligament runs along the midline of abdominal wall.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medial umbilical ligament: The medial umbilical ligament is a remnant of an obliterated umbilical artery.

Option C - Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum, a pouch in the small intestine wall, arises from yolk sac remnants and affects about 2% of people.

Option D - Ligamentum teres:  After birth, the umbilical vein typically degenerates and forms the ligamentum teres, which run from the liver to the umbilicus (belly button).

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely, if a child has a disorder of fatty acid oxidation?

choices.text: Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids
Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances
Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine
Hepatomegaly, elevated serum liver enzymes, and elevated tyrosine

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids:

  • Symptoms of metabolic diseases often emerge after initial feedings, exposing the baby to non-metabolizable nutrients.
  • Inborn errors of metabolism manifest with symptoms such as vomiting, lethargy progressing to coma, hypoglycemia, acidosis, and hyperammonemia.
  • Disorders of fatty acid oxidation lead to carnitine depletion, failure of fatty acid oxidation, and excretion of dicarboxylic acid intermediates.
  • Medium-chain fatty acid oxidation deficiencies may present after illness with calorie deprivation in children aged 2 to 6 years.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances:

  • Galactosemia worsens on exposure to lactose-containing formula, causing hypoglycemia, liver failure, and excretion of urinary sugars (reducing substances).

Options C - Hypoglycemia, acidosis, elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine:

  • Tyrosinemia and maple syrup urine disease worsen after protein feeding, causing elevated levels of specific amino acids and associated complications.

Option D - Alkalosis and elevated serum ammonia:

  • Urea cycle disorders worsen with fasting or protein feeding, leading to excess ammonia production and respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency department at 36 weeks of gestation with spontaneous onset of labor pain. On examination, her vitals are stable, and the fetus's heart rate remains stable at 160 bpm. Further examination revealed a non-tender abdomen, and 3 contractions every 10 minutes were noted. Cervical dilatation is 6 cm. Examination findings are consistent with which stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: first stage

  • There are 4 stages of labor: first, second, third and fourth.
  • The first stage of labor starts from the onset of true labor pain to full cervical dilatation, i.e., 10cm 
  • In the above question, cervical dilatation is 6 cm which is consistent with 1st stage of labor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Second stage 

  • This stage refers to the period from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the baby.

Option C: Third stage 

  • The third stage of labor begins with the delivery of the baby and ends with the delivery of the placenta and membranes. 

Option D: fourth stage 

  • The fourth stage is the observation time for 1-2 hours after delivery of the placenta

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented to the medicine OPD with epigastric pain, weight loss, anorexia, and peripheral edema for the last 2 months. The endoscopic findings are given below in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Associated with CMV infection in children and H. pylori infection in adults
Characterized by foveolar hyperplasia with absent parietal cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Associated with hyperchlorhydria:

  • The above picture shows Menetrier's disease, characterized by finger-like projections
  • It is a rare condition characterized by large mucosal folds in the proximal part of the stomach, decreased acid secretion, and a protein-losing state.
  • TGF-alpha also causes a decrease in the production of acid. The decrease in acid is mainly due to the decrease or absence of parietal cells and indirectly due to stimulation of somatostatin release.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acquired and premalignant condition:

  • Menetrier's disease is an acquired and premalignant condition. It has been seen to be associated with CMV infection in children and H. pylori infection in adults.

Option B - Associated with CMV infection in children and H. pylori infection in adults:

  • It is associated with CMV infection in children and H. pylori infections in adults.

Option C - Characterized by foveolar hyperplasia with absent parietal cells:

  • On histopathological examination, there are foveolar hyperplasia, oxyntic glands atrophy, reduction in chief and cells, and cystic dilation of pits. Edema and hyperplasia of smooth muscle in the lamina propria have also been seen.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed:



What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sign:

  • The given clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of JNAF. The Chopstick sign is seen in JNAF and refers to the appearance of the medial and lateral pterygoid plates resembling separate chopsticks due to erosion of the pterygoid wedge by the tumor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Holman-Miller sign: This sign refers to the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus seen in patients of JNAF.

Option B - Hondusa's sign: This sign refers to an increase in distance between the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and the mandible on a CT scan seen in a patient of JNAF.

Option D - Phelp sign: This sign is seen in glomus tumors and occurs due to erosion of the carotico-jugular spine bone.

questions.text: Which of the following coenzymes is involved in the transfer of acyl groups?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Coenzyme A (CoA), a ubiquitous co-enzyme, transfers acyl groups, which is important for metabolizing fatty acids, cholesterol, and carbohydrates. It facilitates the oxidation of pyruvate in the TCA cycle. 

CoA binds to the acyl group and forms a high-energy thioester bond, which allows the acyl group to transfer to another molecule. The SH group present on co-enzyme A forms thioesters and activates acyl groups for transfer by the nucleophilic reaction. The SH group also activates the alpha-hydrogen on the acyl group for abstraction as a proton.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. NADH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) is a coenzyme composed of two nucleotides, one containing an adenine base and the other a nicotinamide base, with the two nucleotides joined through their phosphate groups. This coenzyme accepts electrons during the oxidation of substrates and donates them to the electron transport chain.

Option C. FADH2 or the hydroquinone form of FAD, is the reduced form of flavin adenine dinucleotide. It donates its electrons directly to the electron transport chain. 

Option D. Coenzyme Q or ubiquinone, is another ubiquitous coenzyme involved in electron transport. It shuttles electrons between complex I and II of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: The oxidation of glucose by the HMP pathway produces which of the following as final products?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 6 NADPH:

  • In the oxidative phase,2 NADPH are produced from 1 glucose molecule to give a final product of ribulose-5-P.
  • To complete the non-oxidative phase, at least three molecules of ribulose-5-P need to enter this phase.

  • To form three ribulose-5-P, 3 glucose 6-P will need to be oxidized initially, out of which 2 molecules are recovered again at the end.
  • Hence, the total reaction of the HMP pathway can be written as:

  • So, in a net reaction, a single glucose molecule is broken down to glyceraldehyde-3-P, 3 CO2, and 6 NADPH.
  • Or, for a complete cycle with 3 glucose-6-P molecules, 6 molecules of NADPH are produced
  • Or we can say the final products of HMP are 6 NADPH

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: Refer to the explanation of A

questions.text:
Diagnostic Criteria for Smouldering Myeloma include all of the following Except?


	Plasma cells in bone marrow: >10%.
	M-component: >30 g/L.
	No evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.
	Evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.
	Plasma cells in peripheral blood - >2,000/µL.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 4,5:

  • Evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient is diagnostic criteria for Multiple Myeloma not Smouldering Myeloma
  • Plasma cells in peripheral blood - >2,000/µL is Diagnostic Criteria for Plasma Cell leukemia

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, D:

  • The diagnostic criteria for Smouldering Myeloma is
  • Plasma cells in bone marrow: >10%.
  • M-component: >30 g/L.
  • No evidence of CRAB or myeloma-like events in the patient.
